Text Mining Wikipedia Article on Donald Trump's Tariffs¶

  • For this programming assignment, I want to extract and analyze text from the Wikipedia article on Donald Trump's tariffs, and then apply sentiment analysis to the extracted text
  • Theoretically, Wikipedia articles are to be written with a neutral and objective tone. Is this true when the article is about controversial political issues? Let's see what the sentiment analysis shows us.
  • https://github.com/DNGMtSac/cisd43files
In [2]:
## Importing Beautifulsoup to use for text mining of wikipedia article

import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
In [3]:
# getting the wikipedia page
url = "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration"
response = requests.get(url) #it sends a GET request to the specified URL and stores the response.
In [4]:
soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')
print (soup)

<div aria-labelledby="firstHeading" class="vector-body" data-mw-ve-target-container="" id="bodyContent">
<div class="vector-body-before-content">
<div class="mw-indicators">
</div>
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
</div>
<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>
<div class="mw-body-content" id="mw-content-text"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Set of tariffs on imported goods to the U.S. instituted in 2025</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Trump_showing_a_chart_with_reciprocal_tariffs_(cropped).jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1095" data-file-width="1348" decoding="async" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Trump_showing_a_chart_with_reciprocal_tariffs_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Trump_showing_a_chart_with_reciprocal_tariffs_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Trump_showing_a_chart_with_reciprocal_tariffs_%28cropped%29.jpg/500px-Trump_showing_a_chart_with_reciprocal_tariffs_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Trump_showing_a_chart_with_reciprocal_tariffs_%28cropped%29.jpg/960px-Trump_showing_a_chart_with_reciprocal_tariffs_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="308"/></a><figcaption>Trump showing one of two<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irishtimes/picture-reciprocal-tariffs_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-irishtimes/picture-reciprocal-tariffs-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> charts of tariffs during his <a href="/wiki/Liberation_Day_tariffs" title="Liberation Day tariffs">Liberation Day speech</a> on April 2, 2025</figcaption></figure>

<div class="hidden-begin mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style=""><div class="hidden-title skin-nightmode-reset-color" style="">Appointments (<div class="hlist inline"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Political_appointments_of_the_first_Trump_administration" title="Political appointments of the first Trump administration">first</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Political_appointments_of_the_second_Trump_administration" title="Political appointments of the second Trump administration">second</a></li></ul></div>)</div><div class="hidden-content mw-collapsible-content" style="text-align:center;">
<ul><li>Cabinets

<hr/>
<div class="skin-invert-image"><span class="notpageimage" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump's signature"><img alt="Donald Trump's signature" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="161" data-file-width="278" decoding="async" height="69" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Trumpsignature2025.svg/120px-Trumpsignature2025.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Trumpsignature2025.svg/250px-Trumpsignature2025.svg.png 1.5x" width="120"/></a></span></div>
<span typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="Seal of the President of the United States" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2425" data-file-width="2424" decoding="async" height="70" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/120px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/250px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="70"/></span></span></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239400231">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .navbar li a abbr{color:var(--color-base)!important}@media(prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .navbar li a abbr{color:var(--color-base)!important}}@media print{.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:none!important}}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Donald_Trump_series" title="Template:Donald Trump series"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Donald_Trump_series" title="Template talk:Donald Trump series"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a href="/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:Donald_Trump_series" title="Special:EditPage/Template:Donald Trump series"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></link></td></tr></tbody></table><p>During <a href="/wiki/Second_presidency_of_Donald_Trump" title="Second presidency of Donald Trump">his second presidency</a>, United States President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> enacted a series of steep <a href="/wiki/Protective_tariff" title="Protective tariff">protective tariffs</a> affecting nearly all <a href="/wiki/List_of_imports_of_the_United_States" title="List of imports of the United States">goods imported into the United States</a>. Between January and April 2025, the average effective US tariff rate rose from 2.5% to an estimated 27%—the highest level in over a century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TW_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-TW-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump escalated an ongoing <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_trade_war" title="China–United States trade war">trade war with China</a>, raising baseline tariffs on Chinese imports to 145%. In retaliation, China imposed a minimum 125% tariff on US goods and <a href="/wiki/Export_restriction" title="Export restriction">restricted exports</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rare_earths" title="Rare earths">rare earths</a> critical to <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">high-tech</a> industries. Trump also initiated a <a href="/wiki/2025_United_States_trade_war_with_Canada_and_Mexico" title="2025 United States trade war with Canada and Mexico">trade war with Canada and Mexico</a> by imposing a 25% tariff on most goods from both countries but later granted indefinite exemptions for goods compliant with the <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement" title="United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement">USMCA</a>. He framed these actions as efforts to hold the countries accountable for contraband <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Drug_trafficking_in_the_United_States" title="Drug trafficking in the United States">drug trafficking</a> and <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Illegal immigration to the United States">illegal immigration</a>, while also supporting <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_in_the_United_States" title="Manufacturing in the United States">domestic manufacturing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump subsequently added a 25% tariff on steel, aluminum, automobiles and auto part imports from all countries.
</p><p>On April 2—a day he called "<a href="/wiki/Liberation_Day_tariffs" title="Liberation Day tariffs">Liberation Day</a>"—Trump announced a minimum 10% tariff on all US imports, effective April 5, and higher tariffs on imports from 57 countries. The announcement of these controversially<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> named "reciprocal tariffs" prompted retaliation from trade partners and triggered <a href="/wiki/2025_stock_market_crash" title="2025 stock market crash">a stock market crash</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to the Trump administration's reciprocal tariff formula, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_deficits" title="Trade deficits">trade deficits</a> are seen as inherently harmful and in need of removal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> a view many economists rejected as a flawed understanding of trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AQ_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-AQ-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HT_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-HT-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WH_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-WH-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MJ_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-MJ-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump also announced he would close the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/De_minimis_exemption" title="De minimis exemption"><i>de minimis</i> exemption</a> for China beginning May 2, and for all countries at a future date.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CE_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-CE-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Higher tariffs on imports from 57 countries, ranging from 11% to 50%, were scheduled to take effect on April 9 but were almost immediately suspended for 90 days for all countries except China. The 10% minimum tariff and the 25% sector-specific tariffs remain in effect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TW_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-TW-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The tariffs have contributed to downgraded <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP_growth" title="GDP growth">GDP growth</a> projections by the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve" title="Federal Reserve">Federal Reserve</a> and <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> and rising expectations of a <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">recession</a>.
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc">
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Background">Background</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Background"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1236090951">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_tariffs_in_the_United_States#2000_to_present:_Deindustrialization_and_wage_deflation" title="History of tariffs in the United States">History of tariffs in the United States § 2000 to present: Deindustrialization and wage deflation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Protectionism_in_the_United_States#1980s_to_present" title="Protectionism in the United States">Protectionism in the United States § 1980s to present</a></div>
<p>Since the 1980s, Trump has advocated for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Import_tariffs" title="Import tariffs">import tariffs</a> as a tool to regulate trade and retaliate against foreign nations that he believes have been disadvantageous to Americans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In his campaigns for the US presidency, Trump promised to use tariffs to achieve a wide range of goals, including preventing war, reducing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_deficit" title="Trade deficit">trade deficits</a>, improving <a href="/wiki/Border_security_in_the_United_States" title="Border security in the United States">border security</a>, and subsidizing childcare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wiseman-2024_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wiseman-2024-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although Trump has said foreign countries pay his tariffs, US tariffs are <a href="/wiki/Fee" title="Fee">fees</a> paid by US consumers and businesses either directly or in the form of increased prices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pogue-2024_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pogue-2024-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wiseman-2024_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wiseman-2024-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He has also claimed that tariff revenues could eventually replace income taxes, however tariffs would only raise $2.4 trillion over the course of a decade, whereas the IRS collects $2 trillion per year;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> furthermore, tariff revenues would be expected to decrease over time, given a presumed reduction of imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Shortly after being reelected, Trump acknowledged that tariffs might cause "some pain" for Americans but insisted "it will all be worth the price that must be paid".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, Trump imposed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Trump_tariffs#Steel_and_aluminum" title="First Trump tariffs">tariffs on steel and aluminum</a> imports, resulting in price increases for Americans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In December 2021, the price of one metric ton of hot-rolled band steel was $1,855 in the US compared to $646 in China and $1,031 in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), a regulator of <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">international trade</a>, later ruled that the implementation violated global trade rules.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While he and his first successor, <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>, rolled back some of these tariffs, most remained in place by the start of Trump's second term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Swanson-2025a_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-Swanson-2025a-27"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump also launched a <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_trade_war" title="China–United States trade war">trade war with China</a> which subjected 60% of US-China trade to 20% tariffs<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and was widely characterized as a failure for the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2019, Trump used tariff threats of up to 25% on Mexico to negotiate an expansion of his "<a href="/wiki/Remain_in_Mexico" title="Remain in Mexico">Remain in Mexico</a>" policy and the deployment of Mexican soldiers to help control <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Illegal immigration to the United States">illegal immigration</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>  Mexico deployed nearly 15,000 troops to <a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="Mexico–United States border">its border with the US</a> and 6,500 troops to <a href="/wiki/Guatemala%E2%80%93Mexico_border" title="Guatemala–Mexico border">its border with Guatemala</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2020, the US, Mexico and Canada renegotiated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NAFTA" title="NAFTA">NAFTA</a> as the <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement" title="United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement">United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement</a> (USMCA) and recommitted to 0% tariffs on most products traded between them. Five weeks after the USMCA went into effect, Trump used an exemption for national security concerns to implement a 10% tariff on Canadian aluminum after claiming it was flooding the US market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He withdrew the tariff a month later, three hours before Canada planned to retaliate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Contrary to Trump’s claim that <a href="/wiki/William_McKinley" title="William McKinley">William McKinley</a> was a steadfast protectionist throughout his entire presidency, McKinley, during his second term,  promoted the clear financial advantages of conducting mutually beneficial trade relations between nations, and recognized that isolationism due to relentless import tariffs would be destructive to the economic health of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Planning">Planning</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Planning"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>While <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">campaigning for his second term</a> as US president, Trump pledged even larger tariffs than <a href="/wiki/First_presidency_of_Donald_Trump" title="First presidency of Donald Trump">his first term</a>, including 60% on China, 100% on Mexico, and 20% on all other countries. He also proposed tariffs to penalize US companies that outsourced manufacturing, such as a 200% tariff on <a href="/wiki/John_Deere" title="John Deere">John Deere</a>. Trump also suggested replacing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Income_taxes" title="Income taxes">income taxes</a> with tariff revenue—an idea economists from the <a href="/wiki/Tax_Foundation" title="Tax Foundation">Tax Foundation</a> deemed "mathematically impossible".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 23 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Memorial_Prize_in_Economic_Sciences" title="Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences">Nobel Prize</a>-winning economists signed a letter warning that Trump's policies, including high tariffs, would "lead to higher prices, larger deficits, and greater inequality".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump appointed close economic advisor <a href="/wiki/Peter_Navarro" title="Peter Navarro">Peter Navarro</a> as his <a href="/wiki/Counselor_to_the_President" title="Counselor to the President">Senior Counselor for Trade and Manufacturing</a>. Navarro had been recently imprisoned for defying <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congressional_subpoena" title="Congressional subpoena">congressional subpoenas</a> related to his role in <a href="/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election">attempts to overturn the 2020 election</a>, including his "<a href="/wiki/Green_Bay_Sweep_(politics)" title="Green Bay Sweep (politics)">Green Bay Sweep</a>" strategy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Navarro advocates for a permanent regime of trade barriers to balance the trade deficit and wrote books criticizing corporations for prioritizing profits over American jobs. He had served in high-ranking trade roles during Trump's first term but was often rebuffed by <a href="/wiki/Free_market" title="Free market">free market</a>-minded Trump administration officials such as <a href="/wiki/Gary_Cohn" title="Gary Cohn">Gary Cohn</a>, who resigned in protest of Trump's 2018 steel and aluminum tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i> reported Navarro would receive more influence and less opposition in Trump's second administration. Navarro began working closely with cabinet nominees <a href="/wiki/Howard_Lutnick" title="Howard Lutnick">Howard Lutnick</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jamieson_Greer" title="Jamieson Greer">Jamieson Greer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/ING_Group" title="ING Group">ING Group</a> noted that plans for Trump's "reciprocal tariff" policy appeared to align with Navarro's section of <a href="/wiki/Project_2025" title="Project 2025">Project 2025</a>, titled "The Case for Fair Trade".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Shortly after the 2024 election, <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Miran" title="Stephen Miran">Stephen Miran</a>, now chairman of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Economic_Advisers" title="Council of Economic Advisers">Council of Economic Advisers</a> under Trump, released a white paper titled "A User's Guide to Restructuring the Global Trading System,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which proposed using tariffs as a tool to drive down the value of the dollar through a negotiated '<a href="/wiki/Mar-a-Lago_Accord" title="Mar-a-Lago Accord">Mar-a-Lago Accord</a>'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GT_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-GT-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Miran and other key figures in the administration have suggested that the dollar is significantly overvalued because of its status as a <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">global reserve currency</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and that tariffs can be used to weaken the dollar and revitalize American manufacturing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> although this view has been criticized by some economists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While the administration's ultimate tariff formula<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Salmon_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Salmon-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> did not closely resemble any of Miran's suggestions, the underlying ideas in Miran's white paper remain important in the Trump administration's conduct of trade policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GT_44-1"><a href="#cite_note-GT-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During <a href="/wiki/Second_inauguration_of_Donald_Trump" title="Second inauguration of Donald Trump">his inaugural address</a> on January 20, 2025, Trump pledged to "immediately begin the overhaul of our trade system to protect American workers and families. Instead of taxing our citizens to enrich other countries, we will tariff and tax foreign countries to enrich our citizens."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On March 4, 2025, the US notified the WTO that it would suspend planned contributions indefinitely. The US was set to provide about 11% of the WTO's $232 million 2024 budget, a fee based on the country's share of global trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2019, the <a href="/wiki/Dispute_settlement_in_the_World_Trade_Organization" title="Dispute settlement in the World Trade Organization">WTO's dispute settlement mechanism</a> has been de facto paralyzed due to the United States vetoing the appointment of judges to the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=WTO%27s_Supreme_Appellate_Body&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="WTO's Supreme Appellate Body (page does not exist)">WTO's Supreme Appellate Body</a>, and without a functioning Appellate Body, no final rulings can be made.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2025)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Legality">Legality</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Legality"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Although the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States" title="Constitution of the United States">US Constitution</a> grants <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">Congress</a> the sole authority to levy taxes, including tariffs, Congress has passed laws allowing the President to impose tariffs for national security reasons unilaterally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In his second term, Trump added tariffs to steel, aluminum, and auto imports under Section 232 of the <a href="/wiki/Trade_Expansion_Act" title="Trade Expansion Act">Trade Expansion Act</a> (TEA), which allows the President to modify imports if the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secretary_of_Commerce" title="Secretary of Commerce">Secretary of Commerce</a> conducts an investigation, holds public hearings, and determines that the imports threaten national security.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christopher-T-Zirpoli-2025_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher-T-Zirpoli-2025-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump directed the <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_United_States_Trade_Representative" title="Office of the United States Trade Representative">USTR</a> to initiate similar investigations to impose tariffs under <a href="/wiki/Section_301_of_the_Trade_Act_of_1974" title="Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974">Section 301</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Trade_Act_of_1974" title="Trade Act of 1974">Trade Act of 1974</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fionta-2020_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fionta-2020-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump also invoked unprecedented powers under the <a href="/wiki/National_Emergencies_Act" title="National Emergencies Act">National Emergencies Act</a> (NEA) and the <a href="/wiki/International_Emergency_Economic_Powers_Act" title="International Emergency Economic Powers Act">International Emergency Economic Powers Act</a> (IEEPA) by declaring <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_emergencies_in_the_United_States" title="List of national emergencies in the United States">multiple "national emergencies"</a> related to border security, energy, and trade deficits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domonoske-2025a_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-Domonoske-2025a-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TI_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-TI-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Declaring these emergencies allowed Trump to enact tariffs quickly without following the complex procedures required by TEA or other trade statutes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While the IEEPA had been used for <a href="/wiki/Economic_sanctions" title="Economic sanctions">sanctions</a>, it had never before been used for tariffs. As he signed the orders, Trump stated that declaring an emergency "means you can do whatever you have to do to get out of that problem."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domonoske-2025a_56-1"><a href="#cite_note-Domonoske-2025a-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>The New York Times</i> reported that "many economists and legal experts believe that the idea of an emergency has been concocted to justify Mr. Trump's desire to impose sweeping import duties without regard to congressional approval or international trade rules."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rappeport_432025_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rappeport_432025-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>To terminate a national emergency under the NEA, a member of Congress can file a privileged resolution requiring their <a href="/wiki/Legislative_chamber" title="Legislative chamber">chamber</a> to vote on the topic within 15 days. In February 2025, <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic</a> Senators <a href="/wiki/Tim_Kaine" title="Tim Kaine">Tim Kaine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mark_Warner" title="Mark Warner">Mark Warner</a> introduced a resolution to end Trump's national emergency on energy, but it was defeated by the Senate's <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Martin-2025_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-Martin-2025-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Senate passed a resolution to terminate the national emergency justifying tariffs on Canada, but the bill is unlikely to pass the House.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A provision was added to the <a href="/wiki/2025_United_States_federal_budget#March_2025_continuing_resolution" title="2025 United States federal budget">March 2025 budget bill</a> to block the process by declaring that the remainder of the year "shall not constitute a calendar day for purposes of section 202 of the National Emergencies Act."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A senate resolution to end the April 2, 2025 "Liberation Day" tariffs emergency failed—with a vote of 49–49 with <a href="/wiki/JD_Vance" title="JD Vance">JD Vance</a> providing the tie breaking vote.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Multinational_tariffs">Multinational tariffs</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Multinational tariffs"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Steel_and_aluminum_tariffs">Steel and aluminum tariffs</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Steel and aluminum tariffs"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On March 12, 2025, the US imposed 25% tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports, aiming to strengthen domestic production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lawder-2025a_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lawder-2025a-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 2, 2025, aluminum tariffs expanded to include empty aluminum <a href="/wiki/Drink_can" title="Drink can">cans</a> and canned beer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TA_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-TA-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The measures expanded Trump's first-term steel and aluminum tariffs by eliminating all exemptions and raising the aluminum tariff from 10% to 25%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christopher-T-Zirpoli-2025_53-1"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher-T-Zirpoli-2025-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The administration argued previous exemptions "inadvertently created loopholes that were exploited by China and others with excess steel and aluminum capacity".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump also mandated that steel be "melted and poured" and aluminum "smelted and cast" in the US to qualify for duty-free status to prevent tariff circumvention.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holland-2025_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Holland-2025-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Commerce Secretary <a href="/wiki/Howard_Lutnick" title="Howard Lutnick">Howard Lutnick</a> said Trump would soon add a copper tariff as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lawder-2025b_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lawder-2025b-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2023, the US imported 44% of its aluminum and 26% of its steel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ONeil-2025_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-ONeil-2025-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Canada was its largest supplier of both, accounting for more than half of aluminum<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCsteel2_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBCsteel2-73"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and two-thirds of primary aluminum imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ONeil-2025_72-1"><a href="#cite_note-ONeil-2025-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While the US was the world's largest producer of aluminum through 2000, it accounted for less than 2% of the global supply by 2021, largely due to high electricity costs that made it <a href="/wiki/Competition_(economics)" title="Competition (economics)">less competitive</a> in the global market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Congressional-Research-Service-2022_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-Congressional-Research-Service-2022-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2021, primary aluminum <a href="/wiki/Smelting" title="Smelting">smelters</a> operated at 55% capacity in the US compared to 95% in Canada and 88% globally. The US remained a major producer of less energy-intensive secondary aluminum, but secondary aluminum is less desirable for defense or electronics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Congressional-Research-Service-2022_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-Congressional-Research-Service-2022-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Automobile_and_auto_part_tariffs">Automobile and auto part tariffs</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Automobile and auto part tariffs"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In January 2025, President Trump announced broad tariffs on Canada and Mexico, threatening the highly integrated North American auto supply chain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domonoske-2025_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-Domonoske-2025-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Due to decades of free trade agreements including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USMCA" title="USMCA">USMCA</a>, factories in the US, Canada, and Mexico grew accustomed to shipping auto parts back and forth multiple times during the manufacturing process.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domonoske-2025_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-Domonoske-2025-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The three largest US automakers—<a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford</a>, <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Stellantis" title="Stellantis">Stellantis</a>—lobbied for exemptions, warning the tariffs would hurt American companies more than foreign competitors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colias-2025_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colias-2025-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Ford CEO <a href="/wiki/Jim_Farley_(businessman)" title="Jim Farley (businessman)">Jim Farley</a> warned investors, "Long term, a 25% tariff across the Mexico and Canadian border will blow a hole in the US industry that we have never seen."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domonoske-2025_75-2"><a href="#cite_note-Domonoske-2025-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump agreed to delay tariffs on USMCA-compliant vehicles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CM_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-CM-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Still, non-USMCA compliant brands manufacturing in Canada or Mexico, such as <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, were affected starting March 4, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colias-2025_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-Colias-2025-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> BMW chose to cover these tariffs until May 1, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The USMCA exemption closed on April 3, when Trump imposed a 25% tariff on all imported cars, including those from Mexico and Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Economist <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Laffer" title="Arthur Laffer">Arthur Laffer</a> estimated car prices would increase by $4,711, compared to $2,765 if the USMCA exemption remained available.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The White House argued the move would boost domestic manufacturing and generate $100 billion in tax revenue,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boak-2025a_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boak-2025a-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> noting that about 50% of the 16 million cars bought by Americans in 2024 were imported.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The same day, Stellantis announced it would temporarily close factories in Canada and Mexico and lay off 900 American employees as it assessed the impact of tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 29, 2025, Trump announced some relief after US automakers requested more time to shift supply chains.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> One order exempted carmakers who pay a 25% on imported cars from other levies, such as on steel and aluminum. A second gave them a rebate on a proportion of tariffs paid for the next two years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While the 25% tariff extended to non-US content in domestically assembled vehicles on May 3, Trump exempted auto parts made in Mexico or Canada complaint with the USMCA.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="De_minimis_exemption_closure">D<i>e minimis</i> exemption closure</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: De minimis exemption closure"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Trump's February 2025 executive orders announcing tariffs on imports from China, Mexico, and Canada initially closed the US <a href="/wiki/De_minimis#Duties_and_taxes_on_imports" title="De minimis"><i>de minimis</i> exemption</a> for imports from all three countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smith-2025_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-Smith-2025-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <i>de minimis</i> exemption waives standard customs procedures on low-value packages to reduce administrative burdens. <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">US Congress</a> quadrupled the <i>de minimis</i> threshold from $200 to $800 in 2016, resulting in an over 1000% increase in shipments claiming the exemption by 2023.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hall-2025_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hall-2025-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kaye-2025_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kaye-2025-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The US threshold was among the highest globally, over five times the size of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>'s, and used by many companies to send goods to the US without close inspection or taxes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kaye-2025_89-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kaye-2025-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The largest beneficiaries were Chinese <a href="/wiki/E-commerce" title="E-commerce">e-commerce</a> companies such as <a href="/wiki/Shein" title="Shein">Shein</a> and <a href="/wiki/AliExpress" title="AliExpress">AliExpress</a>. Some shipments were linked to drug trafficking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hall-2025_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hall-2025-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, by February 7, 2025, Trump reopened the <i>de minimis</i> exemption for all three target countries to avoid overwhelming <a href="/wiki/U.S._Customs_and_Border_Protection" title="U.S. Customs and Border Protection">US customs officials</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNBC-2025_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNBC-2025-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 2, 2025, Trump closed the exemption for <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> again, beginning May 2.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CE_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-CE-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Imports shipped via the <a href="/wiki/Universal_Postal_Union" title="Universal Postal Union">Universal Postal Union</a> (UPU), of which <a href="/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service" title="United States Postal Service">USPS</a> is a member, would be subject to a duty of 120% of the shipment's value or $100 per package—rising to $200 after June 1. Shipments by all other carriers, such as <a href="/wiki/United_Parcel_Service" title="United Parcel Service">UPS</a> and <a href="/wiki/FedEx" title="FedEx">FedEx</a>, became subject to all applicable standard duties—a minimum of 145% for Chinese goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump directed that the <i>de minimis</i> exemption be closed for all countries in the future, once "adequate systems are in place" to collect duties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CE_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-CE-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Following the closure, Chinese e-commerce company <a href="/wiki/Temu" title="Temu">Temu</a> said it would stop selling goods from China directly to US customers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Additional_proposals">Additional proposals</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Additional proposals"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Digital_Sales_Tax_investigation">Digital Sales Tax investigation</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Digital Sales Tax investigation"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Taxation_of_digital_goods" title="Taxation of digital goods">Taxation of digital goods</a></div>
<p>On February 21, 2025, Trump issued a presidential memorandum ordering the <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_United_States_Trade_Representative" title="Office of the United States Trade Representative">Office of the United States Trade Representative</a> (USTR) as well as other officials, including Peter Navarro, to investigate digital service taxes (DSTs) and determine whether to take retaliatory action. A fact sheet accompanying the memo emphasized that the European Union's <a href="/wiki/Digital_Markets_Act" title="Digital Markets Act">Digital Markets Act</a> (DMA) and <a href="/wiki/Digital_Services_Act" title="Digital Services Act">Digital Services Act</a> (DSA) would face scrutiny.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen-2025_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-Allen-2025-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>DSTs are taxes on revenue from digital services, such as online advertising and selling user data. These taxes allow countries to collect revenue from multinational companies that provide digital services in their jurisdiction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen-2025_95-1"><a href="#cite_note-Allen-2025-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> USTR investigations initiated during Trump's first term led to tariff threats on several countries under authority granted by section 301 of the <a href="/wiki/Trade_Act_of_1974" title="Trade Act of 1974">Trade Act of 1974</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fionta-2020_55-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fionta-2020-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On October 8, 2021, over 135 countries participating in the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> negotiations agreed on a two-pillar approach to reform and withdraw DSTs called the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_tax_deal" title="Global tax deal">Global tax deal</a>". The Pillar One deadline was December 31, 2023, but it was subsequently extended to December 31, 2024.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen-2025_95-2"><a href="#cite_note-Allen-2025-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of January 2025, Trump withdrew from Pillar Two of the agreement, and many countries' DSTs remain in effect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen-2025_95-3"><a href="#cite_note-Allen-2025-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Secondary_tariffs">Secondary tariffs</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Secondary tariffs"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>"Secondary tariffs" are a new trade policy introduced by the second Trump administration that resembles <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secondary_sanctions" title="Secondary sanctions">secondary sanctions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Unlike primary tariffs, which directly target a specific country, secondary tariffs penalize the third-party countries or entities that trade with the targeted nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On March<span class="nowrap"> </span>24, following actions such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/March_2025_Venezuelan_deportations" title="March 2025 Venezuelan deportations">March 2025 Venezuelan deportations</a>, Trump signed an <a href="/wiki/Executive_order" title="Executive order">executive order</a> imposing a 25% tariff on nations that purchase oil from <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> at the Secretary of State's discretion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boak-2025b_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boak-2025b-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He subsequently threatened secondary tariffs on countries buying Russian oil, unless Russia agreed to a <a href="/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine#2025_developments" title="Peace negotiations in the Russian invasion of Ukraine">peace treaty with Ukraine</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and on countries that trade with <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Solar_panels">Solar panels</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Solar panels"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>During his administration, President Joe Biden announced preliminary tariffs of 21.31% to 271.2% on Chinese <a href="/wiki/Solar_panel" title="Solar panel">solar panel</a> makers with factories in Malaysia, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Thailand to support American manufacturers complaining of <a href="/wiki/Dumping_(pricing_policy)" title="Dumping (pricing policy)">dumping</a>. The Biden administration raised the alarm over China's high investments in factory capacity for clean energy goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SP_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-SP-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Commerce Department was expected to set final determinations by April 18, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SP_102-1"><a href="#cite_note-SP-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In April, under the second Trump administration, the Commerce Department finalized plans with the lowest tariff at 41%. Products from Cambodia faced duties of 3,521% because its producers did not cooperate with the US investigation. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Trade_Commission" title="International Trade Commission">International Trade Commission</a> will vote on the plans in June.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id='"Reciprocal"_tariff_policy'><span id=".22Reciprocal.22_tariff_policy"></span>"Reciprocal" tariff policy</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title='Edit section: "Reciprocal" tariff policy'><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Liberation_Day_tariffs" title="Liberation Day tariffs">Liberation Day tariffs</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Liberation_Day_tariffs.svg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1398" data-file-width="2754" decoding="async" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Liberation_Day_tariffs.svg/250px-Liberation_Day_tariffs.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Liberation_Day_tariffs.svg/500px-Liberation_Day_tariffs.svg.png 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Map of countries and territories affected by and percentages of the Liberation Day tariffs</figcaption></figure>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Flag_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo.svg/20px-Flag_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Flag_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo.svg.png 1.5x" width="20"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo" title="Democratic Republic of the Congo">Democratic Republic of the Congo</a></td>
<td>11%

<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg/60px-Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a></td>
<td>32%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_Thailand.svg/40px-Flag_of_Thailand.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_Thailand.svg/60px-Flag_of_Thailand.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a></td>
<td>36%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Tunisia.svg/40px-Flag_of_Tunisia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Tunisia.svg/60px-Flag_of_Tunisia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a></td>
<td>28%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_Vanuatu.svg/40px-Flag_of_Vanuatu.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_Vanuatu.svg/60px-Flag_of_Vanuatu.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a></td>
<td>22%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Venezuela.svg/40px-Flag_of_Venezuela.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Venezuela.svg/60px-Flag_of_Venezuela.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a></td>
<td>15%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/40px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/60px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a></td>
<td>46%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Zambia.svg/40px-Flag_of_Zambia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Zambia.svg/60px-Flag_of_Zambia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Zambia" title="Zambia">Zambia</a></td>
<td>17%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Flag_of_Zimbabwe.svg/40px-Flag_of_Zimbabwe.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Flag_of_Zimbabwe.svg/60px-Flag_of_Zimbabwe.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a></td>
<td>18%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>All other non-exempt countries</td>
<td>10%
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Announcement">Announcement</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Announcement"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On February 13, 2025, Trump directed his staff to research both monetary and non-monetary <a href="/wiki/Trade_barrier" title="Trade barrier">trade barriers</a> imposed by foreign countries against US exports and to develop custom "reciprocal tariffs" to counter and penalize each one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rappeport_432025_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-Rappeport_432025-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He instructed them to consider factors such as existing tariffs, exchange rates, and trade balances in their analysis. Lutnick said his team would have a plan ready by April 1, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sherman-2025b_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman-2025b-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump announced that he would unveil the reciprocal tariffs on April 2, 2025, a date he referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Liberation_Day_tariffs" title="Liberation Day tariffs">Liberation Day</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EY-Tax-News-20252_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-EY-Tax-News-20252-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grantham-Philips/AP2_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-Grantham-Philips/AP2-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 2, 2025, Trump declared a national emergency to address what he described as a "large and persistent US trade deficit", enabling him to invoke the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IEEPA" title="IEEPA">IEEPA</a> to impose a 10% tariff on all imports to the US, effective April 5, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TI_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-TI-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He also announced higher tariffs for 57 countries and territories set to begin April 9.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-TR-109"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The White House said these tariffs would be applied in addition to existing measures on Chinese imports, resulting in an effective tariff rate of 54% on Chinese goods after April 9, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Doherty_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-Doherty-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Politico" title="Politico">Politico</a></i> described the measures as "the most significant US protectionist trade action since the 1930s", when Congress passed the <a href="/wiki/Smoot%E2%80%93Hawley_Tariff_Act" title="Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act">Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TI_57-2"><a href="#cite_note-TI-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Federal Reserve chairman <a href="/wiki/Jerome_Powell" title="Jerome Powell">Jerome Powell</a> described the tariffs, and their likely economic impact, as "significantly larger than expected."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Excluded_goods">Excluded goods</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Excluded goods"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The following goods were not impacted by additional tariffs, including the 10% baseline tariff:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>All articles subject to <a class="external text" href="https://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?req=granuleid:USC-2000-title50-section1702&amp;num=0&amp;edition=2000" rel="nofollow">50 USC 1702(b)</a>, such as books and other informational materials</li>
<li>Steel and aluminum products, which were separately impacted by a 25% universal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Section_232" title="Section 232">Section 232</a> tariff</li>
<li>Automobiles and automobile parts, which were separately impacted by a 25% universal Section 232 tariff</li>
<li>Copper, pharmaceuticals, semiconductors, lumber articles, certain critical minerals, and energy and energy products, some of which were under investigation for Section 232 tariffs</li>
<li>Any products that become subject to future Section 232 tariffs</li>
<li>Products from Mexico and Canada compliant with <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement" title="United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement">USMCA</a>, except for goods targeted by Section 232 tariffs</li>
<li>Imports from countries subject to Column 2 of the <a href="/wiki/Harmonized_Tariff_Schedule_of_the_United_States" title="Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States">HTSUS</a>, which at the time were Cuba, North Korea, Russia, and Belarus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Smartphones, computers and various electronic parts<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Development">Development</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Development"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">Reuters</a> reported the Trump administration struggled to design reciprocal tariffs because each of the 186 members of the <a href="/wiki/World_Customs_Organization" title="World Customs Organization">World Customs Organization</a> applied different duties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The administration initially considered dividing all countries into tiers of high, medium, and low trade barriers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloombergcom-20252_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloombergcom-20252-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Later, Treasury Secretary <a href="/wiki/Scott_Bessent" title="Scott Bessent">Scott Bessent</a> and National Economic Council director <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Hassett" title="Kevin Hassett">Kevin Hassett</a> told <a href="/wiki/Fox_Business" title="Fox Business">Fox Business</a> that the administration would focus on the United States' largest trading partners and assign individualized tariff rates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloombergcom-20252_116-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bloombergcom-20252-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EY-Tax-News-20252_107-1"><a href="#cite_note-EY-Tax-News-20252-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Hassett stated that "more than 100 countries don't really have any tariffs on us and don't have any non-tariff barriers" and that only "10 to 15 countries" were a concern.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EY-Tax-News-20252_107-2"><a href="#cite_note-EY-Tax-News-20252-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>However, on March 30 Trump told reporters, "I don't know who told you 10 or 15", dismissing the idea as a "rumor" and saying he would impose tariffs on "all countries".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although many countries attempted to negotiate deals in the weeks leading up to April 2, no exemptions were granted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The lack of clarity contributed to economic volatility and the beginning of the 2025 stock market crash.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kaye/NYT2_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kaye/NYT2-122"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-French/Reuters2_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-French/Reuters2-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_News" title="Bloomberg News">Bloomberg News</a> reported Navarro urged Trump to adopt a 25% minimum import tariff or a "reciprocal" tariff formula based on trade deficits, while Bessent and Hassett proposed more nuanced and targeted tariffs. Bessent encouraged using tariffs primarily as a negotiating tool, while Navarro saw them as a means to transform trade relationships. Ultimately, Trump adopted Navarro's idea of "reciprocal" tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Formula_calculation">Formula calculation</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Formula calculation"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Soon after the unveiling, financial journalist <a href="/wiki/James_Surowiecki" title="James Surowiecki">James Surowiecki</a> reported that the final "reciprocal tariff" policy appeared to calculate the value of a country's trade barriers by dividing the US trade deficit with the country by the value of US imports from the country, where both the trade deficit and the imports focus only on goods, rather than both goods and services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Salmon_48-1"><a href="#cite_note-Salmon-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The "reciprocal" tariff rate Trump imposed was then calculated by dividing that value in half.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTcalc_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYTcalc-127"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> For example, dividing the US's 2024 trade deficit in goods with China, $295 billion, by the amount that the US imported from China, $439 billion, results in the 67% trade barrier value the US assigned to China: $295bn ÷ $439bn = 0.67 which, as a percentage, is 67%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The Trump administration later published their trade barrier formula online, which <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Simplification_(fraction)" title="Simplification (fraction)">simplified</a> to the same formula.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Salmon_48-2"><a href="#cite_note-Salmon-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> With variable <i>i</i> representing a country, <i>m<sub>i</sub></i> representing imports of goods from that country, and <i>x<sub>i</sub></i> representing exports of goods to that country, the formula given by the White House is as follows:
</p>
<div class="center"><span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math alttext="{\displaystyle \Delta \tau _{i}={\frac {x_{i}-m_{i}}{\varepsilon \times \phi \times m_{i}}}}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
<semantics>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
<mi mathvariant="normal">Δ<!-- Δ --></mi>
<msub>
<mi>τ<!-- τ --></mi>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<msub>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
<msub>
<mi>m</mi>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mrow>
<mrow>
<mi>ε<!-- ε --></mi>
<mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
<mi>ϕ<!-- ϕ --></mi>
<mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
<msub>
<mi>m</mi>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle \Delta \tau _{i}={\frac {x_{i}-m_{i}}{\varepsilon \times \phi \times m_{i}}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
</math></span><img alt="{\displaystyle \Delta \tau _{i}={\frac {x_{i}-m_{i}}{\varepsilon \times \phi \times m_{i}}}}" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert skin-invert" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7e7e696d073d1fe1b8ed3c4e13acba7a834f5eba" style="vertical-align: -2.338ex; width:18.676ex; height:5.509ex;"/></span></div>
