<p>The Trump administration formula included measures of <a href="/wiki/Elasticity_(economics)" title="Elasticity (economics)">elasticity</a> set at <i>ε</i> = −4 and <i>φ</i>  = 0.25, then multiplied them for <i>ε</i> × <i>φ</i>  = −1, which resulted in no change except to make the result positive when <i>ε</i> × <i>φ</i>  was multiplied to other parts of the calculation as defined in the formula.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Salmon_48-3"><a href="#cite_note-Salmon-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Thus, with <i>x<sub>i</sub></i> − <i>m<sub>i</sub></i> being the trade deficit for goods, the formula simplifies to Surowiecki's:
</p>
<div class="center"><span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math alttext="{\displaystyle \Delta \tau _{i}=-1\times {\frac {x_{i}-m_{i}}{m_{i}}}}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
<semantics>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
<mi mathvariant="normal">Δ<!-- Δ --></mi>
<msub>
<mi>τ<!-- τ --></mi>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>=</mo>
<mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<msub>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
<msub>
<mi>m</mi>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mrow>
<msub>
<mi>m</mi>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle \Delta \tau _{i}=-1\times {\frac {x_{i}-m_{i}}{m_{i}}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
</math></span><img alt="{\displaystyle \Delta \tau _{i}=-1\times {\frac {x_{i}-m_{i}}{m_{i}}}}" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert skin-invert" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/151befd3e221649904f38cdc30561d5b1ec1cd11" style="vertical-align: -2.171ex; width:21.307ex; height:5.343ex;"/></span></div>
<p>The "discounted" tariff rate is then calculated by dividing the result by 2, making the final formula:
</p>
<div class="center"><span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math alttext="{\displaystyle {\text{reciprocal tariff}}=-{\frac {1}{2}}\times \left({\frac {{\text{exports}}-{\text{imports}}}{\text{imports}}}\right)}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
<semantics>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>reciprocal tariff</mtext>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mn>1</mn>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>exports</mtext>
</mrow>
<mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>imports</mtext>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mtext>imports</mtext>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle {\text{reciprocal tariff}}=-{\frac {1}{2}}\times \left({\frac {{\text{exports}}-{\text{imports}}}{\text{imports}}}\right)}</annotation>
</semantics>
</math></span><img alt="{\displaystyle {\text{reciprocal tariff}}=-{\frac {1}{2}}\times \left({\frac {{\text{exports}}-{\text{imports}}}{\text{imports}}}\right)}" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert skin-invert" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ddb0127b1b8bbcde1f7812cc3038696078aa605c" style="vertical-align: -2.505ex; width:47.522ex; height:6.176ex;"/></span></div>
<p>The Trump administration's <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_United_States_Trade_Representative" title="Office of the United States Trade Representative">Office of the United States Trade Representative</a> (USTR) explained that the tariffs "are calculated as the tariff rate necessary to balance bilateral trade deficits between the U.S. and each of our trading partners", aiming to "drive bilateral trade deficits to zero".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schneid_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schneid-130"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, even countries with which the US runs a trade surplus, such as Australia, received a tariff of 10%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Reactions">Reactions</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Reactions"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>USTR cited research papers by several economists, many of whom publicly criticized the formula and stated the White House had misinterpreted and incorrectly applied their research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WH_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-WH-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Anson Soderbery, whose work was cited, said his research was meant to discourage exactly the types of policies the White House was implementing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WH_13-2"><a href="#cite_note-WH-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Brent_Neiman" title="Brent Neiman">Brent Neiman</a> said the administration used the wrong variable from his research—leading to results four times too high—and that trade deficits reflect economic fundamentals, not unfair trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MJ_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-MJ-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Some economists likened fears over trade deficits to worry about having a "deficit" with a grocery store, emphasizing that buying more than you sell in a mutually beneficial exchange is not inherently problematic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HT_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-HT-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AQ_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-AQ-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Economic experts criticized the formula for being overly simplistic with little relation to trade barriers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WH_13-3"><a href="#cite_note-WH-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> describing it as "almost as random as taxing you on the number of vowels in your name."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>  Some media outlets noted that this was the same formula that was obtained by asking <a href="/wiki/ChatGPT" title="ChatGPT">ChatGPT</a> and other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Large_language_models" title="Large language models">large language models</a> for a global tariff formula that compensates for trade deficit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Treasury Secretary <a href="/wiki/Scott_Bessent" title="Scott Bessent">Scott Bessent</a> told "every country" on April 3: "do not retaliate, sit back, take it in, let's see how it goes, because, if you retaliate, there will be escalation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After the stock market lost significant value the next day, President Trump said events were "going very well" and "markets are going to boom, the stock is going to boom, the country is going to boom."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 6, while the stock markets continued to fall, Trump said that his tariffs "are already in effect, and a beautiful thing to behold."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2025, a <a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">Reuters</a> <a href="/wiki/Ipsos" title="Ipsos">/Ipsos</a> poll found that 73% of Americans expect a price surge under the Trump tariffs while 57% oppose the tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump also saw a drop in his overall approval rating following the announcement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Impacted_regions">Impacted regions</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Impacted regions"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:2025-April-02-so-called-Reciprocal_tariffs.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1730" data-file-width="2290" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/2025-April-02-so-called-Reciprocal_tariffs.jpg/250px-2025-April-02-so-called-Reciprocal_tariffs.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/2025-April-02-so-called-Reciprocal_tariffs.jpg/500px-2025-April-02-so-called-Reciprocal_tariffs.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>A table showing the April 2025 "Liberation Day" tariffs and the claims upon which they were based</figcaption></figure>
<p>The White House's initial list of impacted areas included the <a href="/wiki/Heard_Island_and_McDonald_Islands" title="Heard Island and McDonald Islands">Heard Island and McDonald Islands</a>, a remote uninhabited <a href="/wiki/Antarctic" title="Antarctic">Antarctic</a> territory of Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tiny_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-tiny-145"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A tariff of 29% was proposed for <a href="/wiki/Norfolk_Island" title="Norfolk Island">Norfolk Island</a>, which has a population around 2,000 and also belongs to Australia; the rest of Australia received a tariff of 10%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The initial list also proposed tariffs of 10% on the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Ocean_Territory" title="British Indian Ocean Territory">British Indian Ocean Territory</a>, whose population is solely composed of the inhabitants of the joint American-British military base of <a href="/wiki/Diego_Garcia" title="Diego Garcia">Diego Garcia</a>, numbering some 3,000 American and British military contractors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The decision to impose tariffs on some of these regions appears to have been based on inaccurate trade data. An analysis of United States import records by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> revealed that some shipments were erroneously recorded as originating from remote territories instead of their actual countries of origin. These misclassified imports included items such as wine, aquarium systems, and <a href="/wiki/Timberland_(company)" title="Timberland (company)">Timberland</a> boots.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The highest tariffs of 50% were placed on <a href="/wiki/Lesotho" title="Lesotho">Lesotho</a>, described by Trump as a country that "nobody had ever heard of"; a 50% tariff was also initially proposed for France's <a href="/wiki/Saint_Pierre_and_Miquelon" title="Saint Pierre and Miquelon">Saint Pierre and Miquelon</a> islands, with a population of around 5,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tiny_145-1"><a href="#cite_note-tiny-145"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Other countries facing some of the highest tariffs are Cambodia (49%), Laos (48%), Madagascar (47%), Vietnam (46%), and Myanmar (44%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Exempt_countries">Exempt countries</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Exempt countries"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Six countries were exempted from the reciprocal tariffs: <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, Canada, <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, Mexico, <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>, and Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The White House said that Canada and Mexico were exempted because Trump previously imposed tariffs of 25% on the two countries for non-USMCA goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Press Secretary <a href="/wiki/Karoline_Leavitt" title="Karoline Leavitt">Karoline Leavitt</a> said that Russia had been spared the tariffs because American sanctions on Russia already "preclude meaningful trade" between the two countries, and Treasury Secretary <a href="/wiki/Scott_Bessent" title="Scott Bessent">Scott Bessent</a> said it was because the USA has no trade with Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NK_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-NK-153"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This was despite the value of US-Russian trade being $3.5 billion in 2024, greater than US trade with countries such as <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">Mauritius</a> or <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ravid_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ravid-154"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> who were tariffed by 40% and 24% respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Similarly, Leavitt cited that Belarus, Cuba, and North Korea had been exempted because American sanctions on them were already high.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NK_153-1"><a href="#cite_note-NK-153"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, which has been under American sanctions for 20 years, did receive a heightened tariff of 41%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Walk_back">Walk back</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Walk back"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/2025_stock_market_crash#Tariff_walk_backs_and_market_reversal" title="2025 stock market crash">2025 stock market crash § Tariff walk backs and market reversal</a></div>
<p>The implementation of the tariffs led to a market crash. On the morning of April 9, the head of <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">FX</a> at <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Bank" title="Deutsche Bank">Deutsche Bank</a> told investors, "We are witnessing a simultaneous collapse in the price of all US assets including equities, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_dollar" title="US dollar">dollar</a><span class="nowrap"> </span>... and the <a href="/wiki/Bond_market" title="Bond market">bond market</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TF_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-TF-159"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>That afternoon, Trump announced on <i><a href="/wiki/Truth_Social" title="Truth Social">Truth Social</a></i> that reciprocal tariffs above 10%, which had gone into effect that morning, would be paused for 90 days for all countries except China. China's minimum tariff rate was increased to 145%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HA_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-HA-160"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while imports from all other countries were sustained at the 10% baseline tariff.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Other global tariffs on products like cars, steel, and aluminum remained in effect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The administration exempted goods that were already in transit and that arrive before May 27, 2025, from the new tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>Politico</i> reported that Bessent had flown to Florida a few days earlier to lobby Trump against the tariffs, warning him that the stock market would continue to decline unless he changed course.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that while Navarro was busy meeting with Hasset on the morning of April 9, Bessent and Lutnick took advantage of Navarro's absence to meet with Trump again and convince him to pause the tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After the walk back, Bessent said the pause was meant to provide time for bespoke negotiations with each trading partner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SW_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-SW-166"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump told reporters, "I thought that people were jumping a little bit out of line<span class="nowrap"> </span>... You know, they were getting a little bit yippy, a little bit afraid".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He said he had been watching the bond market, which had shown signs of crashing the night before.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Stocks surged within minutes of the announcement, with the S&amp;P 500 rising 9.52% for its largest one-day gain since 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20250408cnbc-stock_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-20250408cnbc-stock-169"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Citigroup" title="Citigroup">Citi</a> analysts warned, "We do not see the scenario as being as encouraging as markets do," noting that the remaining tariffs still represented a substantial new burden.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Analysts at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Economics" title="Bloomberg Economics">Bloomberg Economics</a> estimated the US's average tariff rate would still rise to 24% from 2% the year prior. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Investment_Management" title="Pacific Investment Management">Pacific Investment Management</a>, one of the world's biggest bond investors, kept estimates of a US recession at 50/50 "even if the 90-day reprieve turns into a longer stint".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 11, the administration announced it would further exempt electronics such as smartphones and computers from the reciprocal tariffs, but warned they may be subject to future Section 232 tariffs. Chinese technology imports would continue to face a 20% tariff.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Trade_conflicts_by_country">Trade conflicts by country</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Trade conflicts by country"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Canada_and_Mexico">Canada and Mexico</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Canada and Mexico"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2025_United_States_trade_war_with_Canada_and_Mexico" title="2025 United States trade war with Canada and Mexico">2025 United States trade war with Canada and Mexico</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:LCBO_-_For_the_good_of_Ontario_-_20250308-1.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="4080" decoding="async" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/LCBO_-_For_the_good_of_Ontario_-_20250308-1.jpg/250px-LCBO_-_For_the_good_of_Ontario_-_20250308-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/LCBO_-_For_the_good_of_Ontario_-_20250308-1.jpg/500px-LCBO_-_For_the_good_of_Ontario_-_20250308-1.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LCBO" title="LCBO">liquor store in Ontario</a> recommending non-American products in response to Trump tariffs, "for the good of Canada". The pictured wines are Chilean.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Three weeks after Trump won reelection, he announced a 25% tariff on all imports from Canada and Mexico unless they took action against illegal immigration and drug trafficking, particularly <a href="/wiki/Fentanyl" title="Fentanyl">fentanyl</a>. Mexican President <a href="/wiki/Claudia_Sheinbaum" title="Claudia Sheinbaum">Claudia Sheinbaum</a> and then-Canadian Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Justin_Trudeau" title="Justin Trudeau">Justin Trudeau</a> sought to de-escalate tensions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While Trudeau noted that less than 1% of illegal border crossings and less than 1% of fentanyl into the US come from Canada,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horsley-2025_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-Horsley-2025-176"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> he unveiled a $1.3 billion security plan for the <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="Canada–United States border">Canada–US border</a> on December 16, 2024.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite these efforts, on February 1, Trump ordered the tariffs to begin February 4, with a reduced 10% rate for Canadian energy products.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horsley-2025_176-1"><a href="#cite_note-Horsley-2025-176"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_News" title="Bloomberg News">Bloomberg News</a> reported that Trump advisors <a href="/wiki/Peter_Navarro" title="Peter Navarro">Peter Navarro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Miller_(political_advisor)" title="Stephen Miller (political advisor)">Stephen Miller</a> led the economic discussions on the tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Donnan-2025_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-Donnan-2025-180"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trudeau and Sheinbaum condemned Trump's actions and threatened immediate economic retaliation, but on February 3, the three leaders negotiated a one-month delay on the tariffs. As part of the agreement, Mexico committed to deploying 10,000 troops to its border with the United States, while Canada pledged to appoint a "fentanyl czar" and continue implementing the border security plan announced in 2024.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Feb3Pause_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-Feb3Pause-181"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In return, Trump pledged to take measures to curb weapons trafficking to Mexico and to collaborate with Canada on a joint anti-crime "strike force".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Phillips-2025_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-Phillips-2025-184"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>However, on February 27 Trump claimed that "drugs are still pouring into our Country from Mexico and Canada" and reaffirmed his planned tariffs,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Breuninger-2025_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-Breuninger-2025-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> leading to their implementation on March 4, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Canada retaliated with 25% tariffs on $20 billion (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$30 billion</span>) in US goods, with plans to expand to $85 billion (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$125 billion</span>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while Mexico prepared its response for March 9.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Journal" title="Wall Street Journal">Wall Street Journal</a> warned the tariffs had "the potential to profoundly reshape relations between the US and two of its biggest trading partners, abruptly reversing America's decades-long project of expanding free trade with its allies."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The onset of the trade war triggered <a href="/wiki/Stock_market" title="Stock market">stock market</a> declines and economic concerns, particularly for retailers and <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_the_United_States" title="Automotive industry in the United States">car manufacturers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Lutnick quickly signaled tariff reductions. "The president is listening to the offers from Mexico and Canada. He's thinking about trying to do something in the middle," he said on March 5.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The same day, Trump delayed tariffs on <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement" title="United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement">USMCA</a>-compliant automakers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colias-2025_76-2"><a href="#cite_note-Colias-2025-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The next day, he extended the delay to all USMCA-compliant goods until April 2.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zahn-2025_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zahn-2025-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While only 50% of Mexican and 38% of Canadian imports were officially compliant in 2024,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zahn-2025_192-1"><a href="#cite_note-Zahn-2025-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> many companies skipped the paperwork since their goods already qualified for low tariffs under <a href="/wiki/Most_favoured_nation" title="Most favoured nation">most favored nation</a> rules. Officials from both countries expected most exports to be compliant within weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Martinez-2025_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-Martinez-2025-193"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Canada kept its initial tariffs but suspended the planned increase.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gillies-2025_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gillies-2025-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Tens of thousands of Mexicans celebrated with Sheinbaum in Mexico City's central plaza.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Although the USMCA exemption was expected to expire on April 2, that day the White House announced it would continue indefinitely. However, Trump signed new orders imposing 25% tariffs on imports of steel, aluminum, automobiles, and auto parts from any country, including Canada and Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CM_77-1"><a href="#cite_note-CM-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Canada, the US's largest supplier of steel and aluminum, was significantly impacted by US tariffs on these products, and retaliated on March 13 with 25% tariffs on an additional $20.6 billion (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$29.8 billion</span>) of US goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SR_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-SR-197"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 9, Canada implemented a 25% tariff on US-made vehicles that are not compliant with the USMCA.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KI_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-KI-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 11, 2025, Trump, threatened Mexico with new tariffs, saying Mexico had not fulfilled a <a href="/wiki/Treaty_relating_to_the_utilization_of_waters_of_the_Colorado_and_Tijuana_Rivers_and_of_the_Rio_Grande" title="Treaty relating to the utilization of waters of the Colorado and Tijuana Rivers and of the Rio Grande">1944 agreement</a> to send 1.75 million acre-feet of water from the <a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande" title="Rio Grande">Rio Grande</a> via numerous dams and <a href="/wiki/Reservoir" title="Reservoir">reservoirs</a>. Trump said Mexico had only fulfilled 30% of the agreed quota.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TM_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-TM-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He added that "Mexico has been stealing the water from Texas Farmers".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Sheinbaum stated that the reason the quota was not fulfilled was due to a "three-year drought", suggesting that an alternative agreement can be reached.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TM_200-1"><a href="#cite_note-TM-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Asia">Asia</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Asia"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="China">China</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: China"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_trade_war" title="China–United States trade war">China–United States trade war</a></div><p>During Trump's first term, the US and China traded multiple rounds of escalating tariff and non-tariff trade barriers beginning in January 2018. In January 2020, the two countries signed a "phase one" trade deal, under which China committed to purchasing $200 billion of U.S. goods and services over the next two years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UC_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-UC-202"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> China failed to meet this target, ultimately importing even less than it had before the trade war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> President Joe Biden largely maintained and expanded Trump's tariffs during his administration,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UC_202-1"><a href="#cite_note-UC-202"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and Trump pledged to impose higher tariffs in his second term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> </p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:2025%E6%97%A5%E4%B8%AD%E9%9F%93%E7%B5%8C%E6%B8%88%E8%B2%BF%E6%98%93%E5%A4%A7%E8%87%A3%E4%BC%9A%E5%90%88_(cropped).jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2465" data-file-width="4488" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/2025%E6%97%A5%E4%B8%AD%E9%9F%93%E7%B5%8C%E6%B8%88%E8%B2%BF%E6%98%93%E5%A4%A7%E8%87%A3%E4%BC%9A%E5%90%88_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-2025%E6%97%A5%E4%B8%AD%E9%9F%93%E7%B5%8C%E6%B8%88%E8%B2%BF%E6%98%93%E5%A4%A7%E8%87%A3%E4%BC%9A%E5%90%88_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/2025%E6%97%A5%E4%B8%AD%E9%9F%93%E7%B5%8C%E6%B8%88%E8%B2%BF%E6%98%93%E5%A4%A7%E8%87%A3%E4%BC%9A%E5%90%88_%28cropped%29.jpg/500px-2025%E6%97%A5%E4%B8%AD%E9%9F%93%E7%B5%8C%E6%B8%88%E8%B2%BF%E6%98%93%E5%A4%A7%E8%87%A3%E4%BC%9A%E5%90%88_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>China, South Korea, and Japan agreed to strengthen free trade in the face of Trump tariffs on March 30, 2025.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In February 2025, Trump declared a national emergency over <a href="/wiki/Illegal_drug_trade_in_China" title="Illegal drug trade in China">Chinese drug-trafficking</a> which he used to justify a 10% tariff on all Chinese imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Donnan-2025_180-1"><a href="#cite_note-Donnan-2025-180"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In March, he increased the tariff to 20%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Breuninger-2025_185-1"><a href="#cite_note-Breuninger-2025-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>China retaliated in February with tariffs of 15% on coals and <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas" title="Liquefied natural gas">liquefied natural gas</a> and 10% on oil and agricultural machines and in March with 10-15% tariffs on select US agricultural products.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xiao-2025_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-Xiao-2025-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPR-2025_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-2025-207"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although these measures were modest in comparison to the US tariffs, China also retaliated with a variety of non-tariff trade barriers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mason-20252_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mason-20252-208"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FT_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FT-209"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>Politico</i> reported that from the start of 2025 China implemented "an array of bureaucratic blocks and tricky third-party sales deals" halt or curtail the direct imports of major US commodities including beef, poultry, and liquefied natural gas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FT_209-1"><a href="#cite_note-FT-209"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Retaliatory measures included <a href="/wiki/Chinese_government_sanctions#Sanctions_announced_by_the_Ministry_of_Commerce_(Unreliable_Entities_List)" title="Chinese government sanctions">blacklisting American companies</a>, adding <a href="/wiki/Export_control" title="Export control">export controls</a> to metals like <a href="/wiki/Tungsten" title="Tungsten">tungsten</a>, and revoking export licenses for US firms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xiao-2025_206-1"><a href="#cite_note-Xiao-2025-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mason-20252_208-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mason-20252-208"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-210"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> China decreased imports of American oil by 90%, turning to Canadian oil instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On March 30, 2025, China, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, and Japan's trade ministers met for the first time in five years to discuss goals for a <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Japan%E2%80%93South_Korea_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="China–Japan–South Korea Free Trade Agreement">trilateral free trade agreement</a> and enhanced supply-chain cooperation in response to Trump tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuters2025china_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-reuters2025china-213"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 2, the US added a 34% "reciprocal tariff" on most Chinese imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> China matched with a tariff of 34% on American goods, effective April 10, 2025,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and suspended negotiations regarding <a href="/wiki/Restrictions_on_TikTok_in_the_United_States" title="Restrictions on TikTok in the United States">the sale of TikTok</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> China also began requiring special licenses to export six <a href="/wiki/Rare-earth_element" title="Rare-earth element">heavy rare-earths</a>, 100% of which were refined in China, and <a href="/wiki/Rare-earth_magnet" title="Rare-earth magnet">rare-earth magnets</a>, 90% of which are produced in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WI_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-WI-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The rare earths, difficult to substitute, are critical to a range of high-tech goods, including batteries, weapons, and medical devices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> China was slow to develop the export licenses and halted all exports in the meantime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WI_217-1"><a href="#cite_note-WI-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump raised the tariffs by an additional 50%, bringing the baseline tariff on Chinese imports to 104%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> China added an additional 50% as well, bringing their baseline tariff on American goods to 84%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The US then raised to 145%, and on April 11, China raised to 125%. The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(China)" title="Ministry of Finance (China)">Chinese Finance Ministry</a> said China would ignore any further US tariff increases, stating, "Even if the U.S. continues to impose higher tariffs, it will no longer make economic sense and will become a joke in the history of world economy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 21, CEOs of major US retailers warned Trump that the escalating trade war would lead to visible price increases and product shortages within two weeks. Trump began to soften his tone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 22, Trump stated that tariffs on Chinese imports would "come down substantially, but it won't be zero".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WT_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-WT-223"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Two days later, Chinese Foreign Affairs Ministry spokesman <a href="/wiki/Guo_Jiakun" title="Guo Jiakun">Guo Jiakun</a> said China and the US had "not conducted consultations or negotiations on tariffs."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WT_223-1"><a href="#cite_note-WT-223"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> When asked to respond, Trump said the US had been meeting with China as recently as that morning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>By May 2, China had exempted approximately $40 billion worth of American goods from tariffs and the United States had exempted about $102 billion worth of Chinese imports, based on 2024 import volumes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-225"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Both countries had expressed a willingness to engage in negotiations aimed at reducing tariffs, but the Chinese government asked the U.S. to fully eliminate its tariffs first. As previously planned, the U.S. terminated the <i>de minimis</i> exemption for Chinese imports the same day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-226"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="India">India</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: India"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:P20250213MR-0996.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/P20250213MR-0996.jpg/250px-P20250213MR-0996.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/P20250213MR-0996.jpg/500px-P20250213MR-0996.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In February 2025, Indian Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a> visited the White House to negotiate tariffs and advance a deal aimed at doubling bilateral trade to $500 billion by 2030.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kumar-2025_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kumar-2025-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> India's trade-weighted average tariff was 12%, compared to the United States' 2.2%, leading to Trump repeatedly calling the country "tariff king" and a "big abuser" of trade ties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singh-2025_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-Singh-2025-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The US was India's largest export market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TT_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-TT-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Analyses projected reciprocal tariff measures would have significant economic impacts to India. <a href="/wiki/Citigroup" title="Citigroup">Citi Research</a> estimated that India could lose $7 billion annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kumar-2025_227-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kumar-2025-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> An internal Indian analysis estimated that reciprocal tariffs would affect 87% of its total exports to the US, valued at $66 billion. India estimated increases of 6% to 10% in tariffs on items such as pearls, mineral fuels, and machinery and believed its $11 billion worth of pharmaceutical and automotive exports would see the highest impact.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singh-2025_228-1"><a href="#cite_note-Singh-2025-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>India took several steps to address trade concerns. In February, it reduced tariffs on motorcycles and whiskey, pledged to review additional tariffs, and offered to increase US energy and defense equipment imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kumar-2025_227-2"><a href="#cite_note-Kumar-2025-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The following month, <a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">Reuters</a> reported that India was negotiating with the US and was open to lowering or eliminating tariffs on 55% of its imports from the US, valued at $23 billion, which were currently subject to tariffs ranging from 5% to 30%. India warned the offer was contingent on relief from reciprocal tariffs and said decisions were not final.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singh-2025_228-2"><a href="#cite_note-Singh-2025-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 2, the US applied a 27% "reciprocal tariff" to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TT_230-1"><a href="#cite_note-TT-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Vice_President_Vance_met_with_Indian_PM_Modi_at_7_Lok_Kalyan_Marg_(2025).jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1366" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vice_President_Vance_met_with_Indian_PM_Modi_at_7_Lok_Kalyan_Marg_%282025%29.jpg/250px-Vice_President_Vance_met_with_Indian_PM_Modi_at_7_Lok_Kalyan_Marg_%282025%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vice_President_Vance_met_with_Indian_PM_Modi_at_7_Lok_Kalyan_Marg_%282025%29.jpg/500px-Vice_President_Vance_met_with_Indian_PM_Modi_at_7_Lok_Kalyan_Marg_%282025%29.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Vice President Vance met with Indian PM Modi at 7 Lok Kalyan Marg.</figcaption></figure>
<p>By April 6, 2025, India signaled that it would negotiate with the United States and would not seek retaliatory tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> There on, India continued with its diplomatic approach, securing a meeting with J.D Vance,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and on April 17, 2025, announcing that they were "considering removing import tax on US ethane".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 29, 2025, the US Treasury Secretary stated that “<a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> would be one of the first trade deals we sign,” reaffirming <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington</a>’s intent to accelerate a resolution and strengthen <a href="/wiki/Bilateral_trade" title="Bilateral trade">bilateral trade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Israel">Israel</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Israel"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On April 2, 2025, Donald Trump imposed a 17% import duty on Israeli goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 3, 2025, Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich would meet with another minister to decide a course of action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LG_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-LG-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By April 7, 2025, Israel had offered to remove tariffs on all US goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:The_White_House_-_54437645928.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/The_White_House_-_54437645928.jpg/250px-The_White_House_-_54437645928.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/The_White_House_-_54437645928.jpg/500px-The_White_House_-_54437645928.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House.</figcaption></figure>
<p>On April 8, 2025, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_prime_minister" title="Israeli prime minister">Israeli prime minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a> visited Donald Trump to discuss multiple topics including tariffs. The US president declined to remove the 17% on Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Japan">Japan</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Japan"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Ishiba_with_Trump_in_the_Oval_Office_February_2025_4.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1734" data-file-width="2600" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Ishiba_with_Trump_in_the_Oval_Office_February_2025_4.jpg/250px-Ishiba_with_Trump_in_the_Oval_Office_February_2025_4.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Ishiba_with_Trump_in_the_Oval_Office_February_2025_4.jpg/500px-Ishiba_with_Trump_in_the_Oval_Office_February_2025_4.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After receiving a 25% tariff on cars and car parts and a 24% tariff on other goods exported to the United States, Japan's <a href="/wiki/Nikkei_225" title="Nikkei 225">Nikkei 225 stock market index</a> fell by 7.8% on April 7, which was the third-largest single-day loss in its history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since Japan is an export-heavy economy and Japan's large automotive sector depends on the United States for 20% of its total exports, Trump's new tariffs had a sizeable effect on the Japanese economy. Analysts estimate that the tariffs could decrease Japan's GDP by 0.8%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CO_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-CO-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:%E7%B1%B3%E5%9B%BD%E3%81%AE%E9%96%A2%E7%A8%8E%E6%8E%AA%E7%BD%AE%E3%81%AB%E9%96%A2%E3%81%99%E3%82%8B%E7%B7%8F%E5%90%88%E5%AF%BE%E7%AD%96%E6%9C%AC%E9%83%A8.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1734" data-file-width="2600" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/%E7%B1%B3%E5%9B%BD%E3%81%AE%E9%96%A2%E7%A8%8E%E6%8E%AA%E7%BD%AE%E3%81%AB%E9%96%A2%E3%81%99%E3%82%8B%E7%B7%8F%E5%90%88%E5%AF%BE%E7%AD%96%E6%9C%AC%E9%83%A8.jpg/250px-%E7%B1%B3%E5%9B%BD%E3%81%AE%E9%96%A2%E7%A8%8E%E6%8E%AA%E7%BD%AE%E3%81%AB%E9%96%A2%E3%81%99%E3%82%8B%E7%B7%8F%E5%90%88%E5%AF%BE%E7%AD%96%E6%9C%AC%E9%83%A8.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/%E7%B1%B3%E5%9B%BD%E3%81%AE%E9%96%A2%E7%A8%8E%E6%8E%AA%E7%BD%AE%E3%81%AB%E9%96%A2%E3%81%99%E3%82%8B%E7%B7%8F%E5%90%88%E5%AF%BE%E7%AD%96%E6%9C%AC%E9%83%A8.jpg/500px-%E7%B1%B3%E5%9B%BD%E3%81%AE%E9%96%A2%E7%A8%8E%E6%8E%AA%E7%BD%AE%E3%81%AB%E9%96%A2%E3%81%99%E3%82%8B%E7%B7%8F%E5%90%88%E5%AF%BE%E7%AD%96%E6%9C%AC%E9%83%A8.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Members of the Second Ishiba Cabinet  convene to discuss U.S. tariff policy.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Shigeru_Ishiba" title="Shigeru Ishiba">Shigeru Ishiba</a> said tariffs were "extremely disappointing and regrettable."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CO_241-1"><a href="#cite_note-CO-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 7, Ishiba talked with Donald Trump by phone, asking the president to reconsider, but could not negotiate any concessions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JR_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-JR-242"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump later wrote "He is sending a top team to negotiate!" on <a href="/wiki/Truth_Social" title="Truth Social">Truth Social</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JR_242-1"><a href="#cite_note-JR-242"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Singapore">Singapore</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Singapore"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On April 2, 2025, Trump imposed a 10% tariff on all goods coming from Singapore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> At an address to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_Parliament" title="Singapore Parliament">Singapore Parliament</a> on April 8, <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore" title="Prime Minister of Singapore">Prime Minister of Singapore</a> <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_Wong" title="Lawrence Wong">Lawrence Wong</a> stated "what the U.S. is doing now is not reform" and "it is rejecting the very system it created." He also stated that "these measures will accelerate the fracturing of the global economy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He also announced the creation of a national task force to support businesses and workers affected by the tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 8, 2025, the Singaporean prime minister's office stated that it would not retaliate on U.S. tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On the same day, a new task force on US tariffs, composed by Singapore’s economic agencies, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Business_Federation" title="Singapore Business Federation">Singapore Business Federation</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Singapore_National_Employers_Federation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Singapore National Employers Federation (page does not exist)">Singapore National Employers Federation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Trades_Union_Congress" title="National Trades Union Congress">National Trades Union Congress</a>, was announced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The task force held its first meeting on April 16, 2025, and was chaired by <a href="/wiki/Gan_Kim_Yong" title="Gan Kim Yong">Gan Kim Yong</a> alongside other political figures such as <a href="/wiki/Desmond_Lee_(Singaporean_politician)" title="Desmond Lee (Singaporean politician)">Desmond Lee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Josephine_Teo" title="Josephine Teo">Josephine Teo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tan_See_Leng" title="Tan See Leng">Tan See Leng</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chee_Hong_Tat" title="Chee Hong Tat">Chee Hong Tat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lim_Ming_Yan" title="Lim Ming Yan">Lim Ming Yan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ng_Chee_Meng" title="Ng Chee Meng">Ng Chee Meng</a> and <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tan_Hee_Teck&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tan Hee Teck (page does not exist)">Tan Hee Teck</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="South_Korea">South Korea</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: South Korea"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Rubio_Meets_with_Japanese_and_Republic_of_Korea_Foreign_Ministers_(54329405775).jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1287" data-file-width="1768" decoding="async" height="182" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Secretary_Rubio_Meets_with_Japanese_and_Republic_of_Korea_Foreign_Ministers_%2854329405775%29.jpg/250px-Secretary_Rubio_Meets_with_Japanese_and_Republic_of_Korea_Foreign_Ministers_%2854329405775%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Secretary_Rubio_Meets_with_Japanese_and_Republic_of_Korea_Foreign_Ministers_%2854329405775%29.jpg/500px-Secretary_Rubio_Meets_with_Japanese_and_Republic_of_Korea_Foreign_Ministers_%2854329405775%29.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>South Korean Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Cho_Tae-yul" title="Cho Tae-yul">Cho Tae-yul</a> and Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Marco_Rubio" title="Marco Rubio">Marco Rubio</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>On April 2, 2025, Trump imposed reciprocal tariffs of 25% on South Korea. With this, the South Korean government announced emergency support for its auto industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 8, 2025, South Korea's acting president, <a href="/wiki/Han_Duck-soo" title="Han Duck-soo">Han Duck-soo</a>, called for negotiation rather than retaliation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump said that he discussed the tariffs with Han in a phone call and South Korea's finance minister will be meeting with US Trade Representative <a href="/wiki/Jamieson_Greer" title="Jamieson Greer">Jamieson Greer</a> for negotiations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 3, Minister of Foreign Affairs <a href="/wiki/Cho_Tae-yul" title="Cho Tae-yul">Cho Tae-yul</a> met with Marco Rubio and expressed deep concern over the reciprocal tariff measures and asked him to take into account South Korea’s investment performance in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 16, 2025, Vietnam's <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Vietnam)" title="Minister of Foreign Affairs (Vietnam)">foreign ministry</a> said that South Korea and Vietnam are seeking to raise bilateral trade to $150 billion by 2030, in a "more balanced and sustainable manner", as they swear co-operation following Trump's tariffs, regardless of "Trump's walk back".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KV_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-KV-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Taiwan">Taiwan</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Taiwan"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:The_White_House_-_54371663219.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/The_White_House_-_54371663219.jpg/250px-The_White_House_-_54371663219.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/The_White_House_-_54371663219.jpg/500px-The_White_House_-_54371663219.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>President Trump announced that TSMC is set to invest in the U.S..</figcaption></figure>
<p>On April 2, 2025, Donald Trump announced a "reciprocal tariff" of 32% on Taiwanese goods,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but excluded semiconductor products, the island's primary exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Taiwan_NYT_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-Taiwan_NYT-255"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump had previously criticized Taiwan for gaining an unfair dominance in the semiconductor industry and not spending enough on its own defense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Taiwan_NYT_255-1"><a href="#cite_note-Taiwan_NYT-255"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Taiwan's government called the tariffs "unreasonable" but chose not to retaliate, instead offering to increase imports from the US and remove all tariffs on American goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:2025%E5%B9%B44%E6%9C%887%E6%97%A5%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E5%8D%93%E6%A6%AE%E6%B3%B0%E8%88%87%E7%AB%8B%E6%B3%95%E9%99%A2%E6%9C%9D%E9%87%8E%E9%BB%A8%E5%9C%98%E4%BB%A3%E8%A1%A8%E5%85%B1%E5%90%8C%E9%87%9D%E5%B0%8D%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E9%97%9C%E7%A8%85%E6%94%BF%E7%AD%96%E8%AD%B0%E9%A1%8C%E6%9C%83%E5%95%86.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1365" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/2025%E5%B9%B44%E6%9C%887%E6%97%A5%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E5%8D%93%E6%A6%AE%E6%B3%B0%E8%88%87%E7%AB%8B%E6%B3%95%E9%99%A2%E6%9C%9D%E9%87%8E%E9%BB%A8%E5%9C%98%E4%BB%A3%E8%A1%A8%E5%85%B1%E5%90%8C%E9%87%9D%E5%B0%8D%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E9%97%9C%E7%A8%85%E6%94%BF%E7%AD%96%E8%AD%B0%E9%A1%8C%E6%9C%83%E5%95%86.jpg/250px-2025%E5%B9%B44%E6%9C%887%E6%97%A5%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E5%8D%93%E6%A6%AE%E6%B3%B0%E8%88%87%E7%AB%8B%E6%B3%95%E9%99%A2%E6%9C%9D%E9%87%8E%E9%BB%A8%E5%9C%98%E4%BB%A3%E8%A1%A8%E5%85%B1%E5%90%8C%E9%87%9D%E5%B0%8D%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E9%97%9C%E7%A8%85%E6%94%BF%E7%AD%96%E8%AD%B0%E9%A1%8C%E6%9C%83%E5%95%86.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/2025%E5%B9%B44%E6%9C%887%E6%97%A5%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E5%8D%93%E6%A6%AE%E6%B3%B0%E8%88%87%E7%AB%8B%E6%B3%95%E9%99%A2%E6%9C%9D%E9%87%8E%E9%BB%A8%E5%9C%98%E4%BB%A3%E8%A1%A8%E5%85%B1%E5%90%8C%E9%87%9D%E5%B0%8D%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E9%97%9C%E7%A8%85%E6%94%BF%E7%AD%96%E8%AD%B0%E9%A1%8C%E6%9C%83%E5%95%86.jpg/500px-2025%E5%B9%B44%E6%9C%887%E6%97%A5%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E5%8D%93%E6%A6%AE%E6%B3%B0%E8%88%87%E7%AB%8B%E6%B3%95%E9%99%A2%E6%9C%9D%E9%87%8E%E9%BB%A8%E5%9C%98%E4%BB%A3%E8%A1%A8%E5%85%B1%E5%90%8C%E9%87%9D%E5%B0%8D%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E9%97%9C%E7%A8%85%E6%94%BF%E7%AD%96%E8%AD%B0%E9%A1%8C%E6%9C%83%E5%95%86.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Representatives from the Executive Yuan and legislative caucuses across party lines convene to discuss U.S. tariff policy.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The new tariffs exacerbated public concerns over the level of support from the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> said that the tariffs were a heavy blow to president <a href="/wiki/Lai_Ching-te" title="Lai Ching-te">Lai Ching-te</a>'s policy of depending on the US to counter China and castigated the government's unpreparedness and ineffective response.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 7, <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the Republic of China">Premier</a> <a href="/wiki/Cho_Jung-tai" title="Cho Jung-tai">Cho Jung-tai</a> convened a meeting at the <a href="/wiki/Executive_Yuan" title="Executive Yuan">Executive Yuan</a> with <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Yuan" title="Legislative Yuan">legislative</a> caucus leaders across party lines to discuss the potential impacts of the US tariff hike on Taiwan. During the meeting, Premier Cho expressed appreciation for their participation and emphasized that the government had completed assessments on both macroeconomic and sector-specific levels. He presented a NT$88 billion plan and urged collaboration between the executive and legislative branches to expedite budget review and implementation, stabilize the economy, and support industries through the challenges ahead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Even after Trump's "walk back", <a href="/wiki/Kao_Shien-quey" title="Kao Shien-quey">Kao Shien-quey</a>, deputy head of the <a href="/wiki/National_Development_Council_(Taiwan)" title="National Development Council (Taiwan)">National Development Council</a>, stated that if the tariffs were ever to be fully re-implemented, Taiwan's manufacturing sector would be likely to see a 5 percent drop in production value.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Vietnam">Vietnam</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Vietnam"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On February 10, 2025, Trump renewed a 25% tariff on all steel imports originally imposed during his first term and increased aluminum tariffs from 10% to 25%. While other countries had previously received exemptions, Vietnam had not, meaning its steel and aluminum exports were already subject to U.S. tariffs. The hike in aluminum tariffs further strained Vietnamese industries and exporters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VE_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-VE-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Vietnam's large trade surplus in goods with the US made it a target for reciprocal tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VE_262-1"><a href="#cite_note-VE-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On March 13, 2025, trade minister <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_H%E1%BB%93ng_Di%C3%AAn" title="Nguyễn Hồng Diên">Nguyễn Hồng Diên</a> arranged a meeting with Lutnick and Greer to try to secure a bilateral trade agreement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He ended up receiving <a href="/wiki/Marc_Knapper" title="Marc Knapper">Marc Knapper</a>, a US Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary Ambassador, on March 14.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thương_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-thương-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Knapper reassured him that the US tariff measures were not aimed at Vietnam and were meant to promote fair trade and American workers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 2, 2025, Trump presented with a 46% reciprocal tariff on Vietnam, shocking Vietnamese exporters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Vietnamese leaders tried to approach Trump diplomatically to find an agreement to remove the tariffs or to delay them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Vietnam's top leader, <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam">General Secretary</a> <a href="/wiki/T%C3%B4_L%C3%A2m" title="Tô Lâm">To Lam</a>, asked President Trump to delay the imposition of tariffs for at least 45 days on April 5, with little result.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Vietnam then offered to eradicate all US import tariffs, but Peter Navarro shot down the deal, saying "it's the non-tariff cheating that matters".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Stock_Exchange" title="Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange">VN Index</a> fell by 7% after the announcement of the tariffs, practically the biggest <a href="/wiki/Stock_market_crash" title="Stock market crash">crash</a> ever since the establishment of the Vietnamese stock market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 15, 2025, <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party">General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party</a> <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a> on <a href="/wiki/State_visits_by_Xi_Jinping_to_Vietnam,_Malaysia_and_Cambodia" title="State visits by Xi Jinping to Vietnam, Malaysia and Cambodia">a visit to Hanoi</a>, claimed that “China’s mega market is always open to Vietnam" and urged Vietnam to resist “U.S unilateral bullying” and uphold free and open trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Donald J. Trump commented the meeting and the proposal, claiming: “That’s a lovely meeting.
