Meeting like, trying to figure out, ‘How do we screw the United States of America?’” Trump told reporters at the White House."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 16, 2025, Vietnam's foreign ministry said that South Korea and Vietnam are seeking to raise bilateral trade to $150 billion by 2030, in a "more balanced and sustainable manner", as they swear cooperation following Trump's tariffs, regardless of "Trump's walk back".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KV_253-1"><a href="#cite_note-KV-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Groundbreaking began on a $1.5 billion previously-announced Trump Organization golf resort near Hanoi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Africa">Africa</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Africa"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Nigeria">Nigeria</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Nigeria"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>During Trump's first term, <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> continued to benefit from the <a href="/wiki/African_Growth_and_Opportunity_Act" title="African Growth and Opportunity Act">African Growth and Opportunity Act</a>, a US trade initiative established in 2000 to improve economic relations with <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan</a> African countries by providing duty-free access to the US market for eligible nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UA_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-UA-275"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, analysts were quick to notice that Nigeria was one of 48 nations with whom the United States maintained a trade imbalance. In 2024, Nigeria exported $5.29 billion in commodities to the United States while receiving $3.88 billion, resulting in a $1.4 billion trade surplus for Nigeria, making it a likely target of Trump's renewed foreign tariff policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UA_275-1"><a href="#cite_note-UA-275"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 2, Trump announced a 14% tariff on Nigerian goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Nigerian government avoided retaliation. Instead, Trade Minister <a href="/wiki/Jumoke_Oduwole" title="Jumoke Oduwole">Jumoke Oduwole</a> said Nigeria would contact the WTO to find a mutually beneficial solution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite pledging not to retaliate, the minister did highlight the risks for AGOA and the Nigerian oil industry, whilst also stating this development had the chance to boost Nigeria's non-oil exports as well as meeting global standards and improving market acceptance into more economies across the globe. She also emphasized the urgent need to enhance intra-African trade through the <a href="/wiki/African_Continental_Free_Trade_Area" title="African Continental Free Trade Area">African Continental Free Trade Area</a> (AfCFTA).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since Nigeria relies on crude exports for 90% of its foreign exchange, immediate consequences were apparent with <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Nigeria" title="Central Bank of Nigeria">Nigeria's central bank</a> selling nearly $200 million to support the <a href="/wiki/Nigerian_naira" title="Nigerian naira">naira currency</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 12, 2025, the Federal Government set up a subcommittee to assess the direct and indirect impact of the recent trade tariffs announced by the United States on Nigeria’s economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On this regard, on April 16, <a href="/wiki/Manufacturers_Association_of_Nigeria" title="Manufacturers Association of Nigeria">Manufacturers Association of Nigeria</a> (MAN) said the 14 percent tariff imposed on Nigerian exports to the United States of America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="South_Africa">South Africa</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: South Africa"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>After Trump announced a 25% tariff on all imported steel and aluminum, major exporters in South Africa were palpable by the onset tariffs,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> leading the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Steel_and_Engineering_Industries_Federation_of_Southern_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Steel and Engineering Industries Federation of Southern Africa (page does not exist)">Steel and Engineering Industries Federation of Southern Africa</a> (SEIFSA) condemning the U.S. tariff hike and warning of negative impacts on local manufacturing, as well as calling on the South African government to take immediate action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump imposed reciprocal tariffs of 31% on South Africa on April 2, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This move, according to the government of South Africa, effectively nullified the benefits African countries enjoy under U.S. trade initiative the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 4, 2025, South Africa's government announced that it would not retaliate and would instead negotiate exemptions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After the reciprocal tariffs were announced, <a href="/wiki/Parks_Tau" title="Parks Tau">Trade and Industry Minister Parks Tau</a> stated that South Africa would start to plan to diversify its export markets, targeting regions in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Another immediate consequence was the postponing of the sale of gems from <a href="/wiki/Petra_Diamonds" title="Petra Diamonds">Petra Diamonds</a>' <a href="/wiki/Cullinan,_South_Africa" title="Cullinan, South Africa">Cullinan Mine</a>, due to uncertainty caused by the tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Zimbabwe"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On April 2, 2025, Trump imposed 18% tariffs on Zimbabwe as part of its "reciprocal tariffs" policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 6, 2025, Zimbabwe became the first country to scrap tariffs on all US goods. The president of Zimbabwe, <a href="/wiki/Emmerson_Mnangagwa" title="Emmerson Mnangagwa">Emmerson Mnangagwa</a>, has stated that the move was made to foster a positive relationship with Donald Trump's government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Europe">Europe</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Europe"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="European_Union">European Union</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: European Union"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><p>
Before his second inauguration, Trump threatened to impose tariffs on the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU) unless it reduced its trade surplus with the US by increasing imports of American cars, agricultural products, and oil and gas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> pointed out that while the US ran a trade deficit with the EU in goods, it was offset by a trade surplus in services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-EU-293"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> </p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:President_Donald_J._Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_French_President_Emmanuel_Macron_(54350966064).jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/President_Donald_J._Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_French_President_Emmanuel_Macron_%2854350966064%29.jpg/250px-President_Donald_J._Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_French_President_Emmanuel_Macron_%2854350966064%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/President_Donald_J._Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_French_President_Emmanuel_Macron_%2854350966064%29.jpg/500px-President_Donald_J._Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_French_President_Emmanuel_Macron_%2854350966064%29.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>French President Emmanuel Macron holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House.</figcaption></figure>
<p>On February 2, 2025, Trump told reporters he planned to impose tariffs on the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> "pretty soon". Some EU leaders threatened immediate retaliation while others expressed concerns about <a href="/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge" title="2021–2023 inflation surge">reigniting global inflation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Armstrong-2025_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-Armstrong-2025-294"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> "We have to do everything to avoid this totally unnecessary and stupid tariff war," said Polish Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Armstrong-2025_294-1"><a href="#cite_note-Armstrong-2025-294"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On February 4, 2025, EU trade ministers met in <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> to discuss Trump's threats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On February 7, the EU proposed lowering tariffs on car imports from 10% to closer to the US' 2.5% rate and to increase purchases of American liquefied natural gas and military equipment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> French President <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron" title="Emmanuel Macron">Emmanuel Macron</a> met with Trump on February 25 and encouraged him to concentrate on China instead of initiating a trade war with the EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Leali-2025_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-Leali-2025-299"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The-Times-of-India-2025_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-The-Times-of-India-2025-300"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-France-24-2025_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-France-24-2025-301"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:President_Donald_Trump_with_Taoiseach_Miche%C3%A1l_Martin.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/President_Donald_Trump_with_Taoiseach_Miche%C3%A1l_Martin.jpg/250px-President_Donald_Trump_with_Taoiseach_Miche%C3%A1l_Martin.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/President_Donald_Trump_with_Taoiseach_Miche%C3%A1l_Martin.jpg/500px-President_Donald_Trump_with_Taoiseach_Miche%C3%A1l_Martin.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Taoiseach Micheál Martin holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House..</figcaption></figure>
<p>On March 12, Donald Trump claimed during his meeting with <a href="/wiki/Taoiseach" title="Taoiseach">Taoiseach</a> <a href="/wiki/Miche%C3%A1l_Martin" title="Micheál Martin">Micheál Martin</a> at the White House that <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> was taking advantage of America. He also referred to the "tremendous" trade surplus that Ireland had with the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After Trump’s global steel and aluminum tariffs took effect on the same day, the EU announced a two-phase retaliatory plan targeting €26 billion in US imports, set to begin April 1.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shalvey-2025_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-Shalvey-2025-303"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Phase one reinstated tariffs on iconic American products, such as <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_whiskey" title="Bourbon whiskey">bourbon whiskey</a>, originally imposed during Trump’s first term tariffs and suspended in 2023 after negotiations with President Joe Biden.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rankin-2025_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rankin-2025-304"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Phase two would impose tariffs on an additional €18 billion in U.S. industrial and agricultural goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shalvey-2025_303-1"><a href="#cite_note-Shalvey-2025-303"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump condemned the EU’s planned 50% whiskey tariff and threatened 200% tariffs on EU alcohol in response.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBC-News-2025_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-NBC-News-2025-306"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The EU postponed retaliation to mid-April, and ultimately dropped all alcohol tariffs after lobbying from Ireland, Italy, and France, major exporters of wine and spirits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bishop-2025_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bishop-2025-307"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>
On March 27, 2025, the United States imposed a 25% tariff on all car imports, significantly affecting Germany, the world's largest automobile exporter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boak-2025a_81-1"><a href="#cite_note-Boak-2025a-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 2, former President Donald Trump announced a 20% tariff on all European Union imports, effective April 9, as part of his "reciprocal tariff" policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In response, EU leaders offered the United States a "zero-for-zero" tariff agreement on industrial goods, such as automobiles, pharmaceuticals, and machinery, on April 7. A similar deal had nearly been reached during negotiations over the proposed <a href="/wiki/Transatlantic_Trade_and_Investment_Partnership" title="Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership">Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership</a>, which Trump halted during his first term. At the time, the EU’s average tariff on non-agricultural goods stood at 1.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:President_Donald_Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_Prime_Minister_Giorgia_Meloni_of_Italy_(5446029292).jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/President_Donald_Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_Prime_Minister_Giorgia_Meloni_of_Italy_%285446029292%29.jpg/250px-President_Donald_Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_Prime_Minister_Giorgia_Meloni_of_Italy_%285446029292%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/President_Donald_Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_Prime_Minister_Giorgia_Meloni_of_Italy_%285446029292%29.jpg/500px-President_Donald_Trump_holds_a_bilateral_meeting_with_Prime_Minister_Giorgia_Meloni_of_Italy_%285446029292%29.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Italian PM Giorgia Meloni holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House.</figcaption></figure><p>On April 9, the EU approved a reduced package of 25% retaliatory tariffs on €21 billion worth of US imports, set to take effect on April 15.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RT_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-RT-311"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The targeted goods were selected to be easily sourced from alternative suppliers, with some measures strategically aimed at US <a href="/wiki/Red_states_and_blue_states" title="Red states and blue states">red states</a>. The only dissenting EU member was Hungary, whose prime minister, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Orb%C3%A1n" title="Viktor Orbán">Viktor Orbán</a>, is one of Trump’s strongest supporters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RT_311-1"><a href="#cite_note-RT-311"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>  However, Trump delayed the implementation of certain tariffs for 90 days, reducing the baseline rate on EU imports from 20% to 10%. In response, the EU suspended its retaliatory measures for the same period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>European Commission President <a href="/wiki/Ursula_von_der_Leyen" title="Ursula von der Leyen">Ursula von der Leyen</a> warned that if negotiations failed by the end of the 90-day window, the EU would initiate what she described as "EU trade bazooka measures."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> She indicated that further countermeasures would target the United States' substantial services surplus with the EU. Von der Leyen also stated that the EU would not tolerate the redirection of Chinese exports hit by US tariffs into the European market, and suggested plans to implement regulatory measures to limit such imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Italian PM <a href="/wiki/Giorgia_Meloni" title="Giorgia Meloni">Giorgia Meloni</a> visited Trump at the White House on April 17, aiming to convince him to accept the EU's "zero-for-zero" tariff offer for industrial goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Russia_and_Belarus">Russia and Belarus</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Russia and Belarus"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Customs_Tariff" title="Russian Customs Tariff">Russian Customs Tariff</a></div>
<p>Russia joined the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> in 2012, requiring all other members to grant it <a href="/wiki/Most_favoured_nation" title="Most favoured nation">most favored nation</a> (MFN) tariff rates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-H42_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-H42-316"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> in 2022, the <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a> countries and their allies moved to revoke MFN status from Russia and block Belarus from joining the WTO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After the United States congress voted to sever normal trade relations with Russia and Belarus, the countries became subject to "Column 2" rates in the <a href="/wiki/Harmonized_Tariff_Schedule_of_the_United_States" title="Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States">Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-RR-320"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Column 2 rates, as created by the <a href="/wiki/Smoot%E2%80%93Hawley_Tariff_Act" title="Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act">Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act</a>, are significantly higher than normal and average about 20% overall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RR_320-1"><a href="#cite_note-RR-320"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> President Joe Biden further increased rates on a variety of Russian goods in February 2023.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Russia added the US to their "<a href="/wiki/Unfriendly_countries_list" title="Unfriendly countries list">unfriendly countries list</a>" in 2021 and imposed countersanctions in response to US measures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump did not include Russia or Belarus in his "reciprocal tariff" policy announced April 2, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HE_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-HE-323"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RE_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-RE-324"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The White House explained that existing sanctions on the country had "already rendered trade between the two countries as zero."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HE_323-1"><a href="#cite_note-HE-323"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RE_324-1"><a href="#cite_note-RE-324"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> US trade with Russia in 2024 was estimated at $3.5 billion, a tenth of the $35 billion from 2021 before it invaded Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Axios$3.5B_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-Axios$3.5B-325"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In an interview with <a href="/wiki/Izvestia" title="Izvestia">Izvestia</a> on April 9, Deputy Prime Minister <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alexei_Overchuk" title="Alexei Overchuk">Alexei Overchuk</a> reiterated that that Russia had no significant trade with the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump threatened "secondary sanctions" on imports from countries buying <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Russia" title="Petroleum industry in Russia">Russian oil</a>, saying, "That would be that if you buy oil from Russia, you can’t do business in the United States. There will be a 25 percent tariff on all oil, a 25 to 50-point tariff on all oil."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="United_Kingdom">United Kingdom</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: United Kingdom"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Starmer-Trump_bilateral_2025-02-27-17-54.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="4706" data-file-width="7044" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Starmer-Trump_bilateral_2025-02-27-17-54.jpg/250px-Starmer-Trump_bilateral_2025-02-27-17-54.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Starmer-Trump_bilateral_2025-02-27-17-54.jpg/500px-Starmer-Trump_bilateral_2025-02-27-17-54.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>British Prime Minister Keir Starmer holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The United Kingdom chose not to retaliate against President Trump's metal tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lawder-2025a_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lawder-2025a-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Reeves" title="Rachel Reeves">Rachel Reeves</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a> stated that discussions were "ongoing" regarding a potential reduction of the UK's Digital Services Tax (DST) to prevent further trade disputes with the United States. Introduced in 2020, the UK's DST imposes a 2% levy on large digital companies, generating approximately £800 million annually. The proposal to reduce the tax faced criticism from the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Democrats_(UK)" title="Liberal Democrats (UK)">Liberal Democrats</a>, who condemned it as a "tax handout to Elon Musk, Zuckerberg, and other US tech barons" and instead advocated for an increase to 6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wwwbbccom-2025_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-wwwbbccom-2025-328"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 3, 2025, the UK government published a 417-page list, which asked British businesses to point to products where tariffs would hurt British companies the least.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 15, 2025, Vice President J.D Vance stated that there was a "'Good chance" of a US-UK trade deal to be signed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Norway">Norway</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Norway"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:President_Donald_Trump_poses_for_a_photo_with_Prime_Minister_Gahr_Store_of_Norway_(54475967533).jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/President_Donald_Trump_poses_for_a_photo_with_Prime_Minister_Gahr_Store_of_Norway_%2854475967533%29.jpg/250px-President_Donald_Trump_poses_for_a_photo_with_Prime_Minister_Gahr_Store_of_Norway_%2854475967533%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/President_Donald_Trump_poses_for_a_photo_with_Prime_Minister_Gahr_Store_of_Norway_%2854475967533%29.jpg/500px-President_Donald_Trump_poses_for_a_photo_with_Prime_Minister_Gahr_Store_of_Norway_%2854475967533%29.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>Norwegian Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House.</figcaption></figure>
<p>On April 24, 2025, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_Prime_Minister" title="Norwegian Prime Minister">Norwegian Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Gahr_St%C3%B8re" title="Jonas Gahr Støre">Jonas Gahr Støre</a> and Finance Minister <a href="/wiki/Jens_Stoltenberg" title="Jens Stoltenberg">Jens Stoltenberg</a> convened with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House to engage in discussions concerning trade tariffs and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="North_America">North America</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: North America"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="El_Salvador">El Salvador</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: El Salvador"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:The_White_House_-_54452406354.jpg"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/The_White_House_-_54452406354.jpg/250px-The_White_House_-_54452406354.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/The_White_House_-_54452406354.jpg/500px-The_White_House_-_54452406354.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>El Salvadoran president Nayib Bukele holds talks with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House.</figcaption></figure>
<p>On April 2, 2025, Trump imposed reciprocal tariffs of 10% on El Salvador.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Two days later, El Salvadoran president, <a href="/wiki/Nayib_Bukele" title="Nayib Bukele">Nayib Bukele</a>, hailed the move as a great idea, stating that long-term thinking was better than short term thinking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Oceania">Oceania</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Oceania"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Australia">Australia</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Australia"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On February 4, 2025, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Chalmers" title="Jim Chalmers">Treasurer Jim Chalmers</a> addressed concerns regarding potential U.S. tariffs on Australian imports, mentioning that whilst he did not rule out the possibility of imposing counter-tariffs in case Trump targeted Australia, he preferred to avoid retaliatory measures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After the announcement of a 25% tariff on steel and aluminum, <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Albanese" title="Anthony Albanese">Prime Minister Anthony Albanese</a> engaged in discussions with U.S. President Donald Trump to achieve some kind of exemption, which ended up with a statement from the White House which expressed concerns about Australia allegedly disregarding past commitments to restrain aluminum exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite Albanese's efforts, the U.S. officially imposed a 25% tariff on Australian steel and aluminum, leading to him calling it an "unjustified" action, however confirming that Australia would not retaliate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite this, Trade Minister <a href="/wiki/Don_Farrell" title="Don Farrell">Don Farrell</a> continuously attempted to achieve some kind of exemption through negotiations, but to no avail.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Donald Trump imposed a 10% tariff on Australia as part of the "reciprocal tariffs" on April 2, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 3, 2025, Prime Minister of Australia Anthony Albanese stated that he would negotiate with the United States to remove tariffs and would not impose reciprocal tariffs as he believed that trade wars are a race to the bottom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LG_236-1"><a href="#cite_note-LG-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In reaction to the tariffs, Prime Minister Albanese released a five-point strategy to mitigate the damage inflicted upon impacted industries.  The strategy includes a $50 million assistance package to help industries like beef exports find new customers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 9, 2025, Australia declined China's ambassador to Australia <a href="/wiki/Xiao_Qian_(diplomat)" title="Xiao Qian (diplomat)">Xiao Qian</a> offer to 'join hands' on Trump's tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Fiji">Fiji</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Fiji"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On February 4, 2025, <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Commerce,_Trade,_Tourism_and_Transport_(Fiji)" title="Ministry of Commerce, Trade, Tourism and Transport (Fiji)">Fiji's Minister for Trade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manoa_Kamikamica" title="Manoa Kamikamica">Manoa Kamikamica</a>, stated that, while it was premature to determine the effects on <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a> as a result of the 25% tariffs imposed on Canada, Mexico, and China, there were concerns that this was the first step toward a global trade war that would also engulf Fiji, fearing that Fiji could become one of Trump's future targets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>However, on February 19, 2025, Acting Prime Minister and Minister for Finance <a href="/wiki/Biman_Prasad" title="Biman Prasad">Professor Biman Prasad</a>, countered Manoa's earlier preoccupations and instead suggested that the tariffs on Canada, Mexico, and China won't affect Fiji, and instead, they might have brought benefits to Fiji, stating that "countries like Fiji could see cheaper goods flowing through the Pacific as these nations look to offload excess capacity".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Professor Biman Prasad later added 3 days later that Fiji's economic fundamentals had improved during the last two years and affirmed that the administration did not see any immediate risks that may disrupt its economic prospects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Even so, Fijian analysts continued to speculate that the increased price of imported aluminum and steel could impact the Fijian economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 2, Donald Trump announced "reciprocal tariffs" on Fiji, amounting to 32%, despite the Fijian government only imposing less than 2% import duties on average on all U.S. imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sitiveni_Rabuka" title="Sitiveni Rabuka">Fijian Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka</a> admitted that his government was not ready for Donald Trump's 'reciprocal tariffs' and was caught by surprise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FH_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FH-346"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Regarding his possible plans going forward, he then stated that, "The world is bigger than the United States" and that Fiji would have to look at new sources of imports and new markets for their exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FH_346-1"><a href="#cite_note-FH-346"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The immediate effects of such tariffs hit products such as <a href="/wiki/Fiji_Water" title="Fiji Water">Fiji Water</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kava" title="Kava">kava</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dalo" title="Dalo">dalo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turmeric" title="Turmeric">turmeric</a>, which are amongst the biggest exported products from Fiji towards the USA.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Fiji's Finance Minister said that the 32 percent tariff by the Trump Administration – the highest in the Pacific – is unfair, while a government spokesperson said he did not understand how the region threatens the American economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 10, 2025, following Trump's "walk back", Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade Manoa Kamikamica announced that a meeting with United States Trade Representatives was set to happen the following week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="South_America">South America</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: South America"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Brazil">Brazil</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Brazil"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The US ran a trade surplus of $253 million with Brazil in 2024.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Nonetheless, Trump criticized the country for being a "tremendous tariff maker" and pledged to impose tariffs on its exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Brazilian president <a href="/wiki/Luiz_In%C3%A1cio_Lula_da_Silva" title="Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva">Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva</a> vowed to reciprocate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, following Trump's 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum, Brazilian Institutional Affairs Minister <a href="/wiki/Alexandre_Padilha" title="Alexandre Padilha">Alexandre Padilha</a> said that Brazil would not retaliate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 2, 2025, Donald Trump imposed the base 10% tariff on Brazil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The reaction from Brazilian exporters was mixed. Coffee exporters saw an opportunity to send more <a href="/wiki/Coffea_canephora" title="Coffea canephora">robusta beans</a> to the US due to international rivals being intially hit with heavier charges,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while other companies, such as <a href="/wiki/Embraer" title="Embraer">Embraer</a>, worried over rising complexity and costs for their US customers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 3, 2025, Brazil's government stated that it would explore options including involving the World Trade Organization. The <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_National_Congress" title="Brazilian National Congress">Brazilian National Congress</a> passed a "Trade Reciprocity Law", enabling the government to respond to potential unilateral trade measures imposed against Brazillian goods and services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LG_236-2"><a href="#cite_note-LG-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Colombia">Colombia</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Colombia"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On January 26, 2025, <a href="/wiki/Colombia%E2%80%93United_States_relations#21st_century" title="Colombia–United States relations">a dispute arose between Colombia and the US</a> after Colombian president <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Petro" title="Gustavo Petro">Gustavo Petro</a> refused to allow the landing of two US military aircraft carrying <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mass_deportation_of_illegal_immigrants_in_the_second_presidency_of_Donald_Trump" title="Mass deportation of illegal immigrants in the second presidency of Donald Trump">deported</a> Colombian nationals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBC-News-2025a_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-NBC-News-2025a-358"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Petro called the treatment of deportees on military flights undignified and said he would accept deportation flights on civilian planes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stewart-2025_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-Stewart-2025-359"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In response, Trump ordered retaliation against Colombia and its officials,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stewart-2025_359-1"><a href="#cite_note-Stewart-2025-359"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> including 25 percent tariffs that would increase to 50 percent in one week if Petro did not reverse his position.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Petro responded by ordering a 25 percent tariff on the US that would also increase to 50 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stewart-2025_359-2"><a href="#cite_note-Stewart-2025-359"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Hours later, the US said Colombia had agreed to "unrestricted acceptance" of deportees, including on military aircraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnn20250126-2330_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-cnn20250126-2330-361"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Colombia said it would "continue to receive" deported Colombians and would guarantee them "dignified conditions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBC-News-2025a_358-1"><a href="#cite_note-NBC-News-2025a-358"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Other_countries">Other countries</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Other countries"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="BRICS">BRICS</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: BRICS"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In November 2024 and again in January 2025, Trump attempted to threaten <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a> countries saying they would face 100% tariffs if they attempted to replace the US dollar as a <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">reserve currency</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Eurasian_Economic_Union">Eurasian Economic Union</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Eurasian Economic Union"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>As of April 3, 2025, according to <a href="/wiki/Kommersant" title="Kommersant">Kommersant</a>'s source in the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Commission" title="Eurasian Economic Commission">Eurasian Economic Commission</a>, which regulates the import duties of the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Union" title="Eurasian Economic Union">Eurasian Economic Union</a> countries, they are unlikely to change – this is a well-established opinion. "The Union as a whole is not significantly affected by the tariff increase, most countries will be subject to a duty of 10%, which in the new realities can be considered the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Most_favourable_treatment" title="Most favourable treatment">most favourable treatment</a>". At the same time, Russia itself has sufficient freedom to impose unilateral restrictive measures, which often happened after 2022. If Russia finds itself hit by other countries raising duties in response to a US import tariff hike, it will still have the option to respond accordingly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kommersant.ru_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-kommersant.ru-363"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Impacts">Impacts</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Impacts"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Markets">Markets</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Markets"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2025_stock_market_crash" title="2025 stock market crash">2025 stock market crash</a></div>
<p>Immediately after Trump's announcement on April 2, markets sunk sharply lower. In Japanese markets, the <a href="/wiki/Nikkei_225" title="Nikkei 225">Nikkei 225</a> dropped 2.8% while the <a href="/wiki/TOPIX" title="TOPIX">TOPIX</a> dropped 3.1%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In Europe, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FTSE_100" title="FTSE 100">FTSE 100</a> was down 1.6%, while the <a href="/wiki/CAC_40" title="CAC 40">CAC 40</a> in Paris fell 3.3%. The German <a href="/wiki/DAX" title="DAX">DAX</a> also fell 3.1%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the United States, stock <a href="/wiki/Futures_contract" title="Futures contract">futures</a> tied to the <a href="/wiki/S%26P_500" title="S&amp;P 500">S&amp;P 500</a> fell 3.9%. <a href="/wiki/Dow_Jones_Industrial_Average" title="Dow Jones Industrial Average">Dow Jones Industrial Average</a> futures fell 2.7%, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nasdaq_100" title="Nasdaq 100">Nasdaq 100</a> futures fell 4.7%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 3, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%26P_500_Index" title="S&amp;P 500 Index">S&amp;P 500 Index</a> fell over 274 points or 4.88%, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_daily_changes_in_the_S%26P_500_Index" title="List of largest daily changes in the S&amp;P 500 Index">second largest daily point loss ever</a>; this was largely attributed to the tariff announcement on April 2.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SC_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-SC-367"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Also on that day, the <a href="/wiki/Nasdaq_Composite" title="Nasdaq Composite">Nasdaq Composite</a> fell over 1,050 points or 5.97%, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_daily_changes_in_the_Nasdaq_Composite" title="List of largest daily changes in the Nasdaq Composite">largest point loss in its history.</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SC_367-1"><a href="#cite_note-SC-367"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1,679.39 points, or 3.98%, then the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_daily_changes_in_the_Dow_Jones_Industrial_Average" title="List of largest daily changes in the Dow Jones Industrial Average">fifth-largest point loss in its history</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SC_367-2"><a href="#cite_note-SC-367"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 4, markets continued losses. The S&amp;P 500 fell 5.97%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SM_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-SM-368"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Nasdaq Composite fell by 962.82 points or 5.82%, also entering into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bear_market" title="Bear market">bear market</a> territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SM_368-1"><a href="#cite_note-SM-368"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The DJIA fell 2231.07 points, or 5.50%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SM_368-2"><a href="#cite_note-SM-368"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> its third-largest point loss in history. The <a href="/wiki/VIX" title="VIX">CBOE Volatility Index</a> (VIX), widely known as "Wall Street's fear index", gained 15.29 points, closing at 45.31 points, the highest close since 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 3, the Russell 2000 entered the bear market territory, falling over 20% from a recent high, after falling 134.82 points or 6.59%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SC_367-3"><a href="#cite_note-SC-367"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Nasdaq Composite did the same on April 4.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SM_368-3"><a href="#cite_note-SM-368"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Across April 3 and 4, U.S. stocks lost $6.6 trillion in value, their largest two-day loss in history by a margin of $2.2 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 7, early trading in Japan triggered the <a href="/wiki/Trading_curb" title="Trading curb">circuit breaker</a> on futures trading after an 8.03% fall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="United_States">United States</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: United States"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Economic_impacts">Economic impacts</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Economic impacts"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:RichmondfedAETRgraph.png"><img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="725" data-file-width="1040" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a7/RichmondfedAETRgraph.png/250px-RichmondfedAETRgraph.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a7/RichmondfedAETRgraph.png/500px-RichmondfedAETRgraph.png 1.5x" width="250"/></a><figcaption>A graph of Average Effective Tariff Rate (AETR) by industry in the United States, as calculated by analysts at the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve_Bank_of_Richmond" title="Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond">Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond</a>, as of April 9, 2025.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Although Trump's first term economic policy featured lower and more targeted tariffs with many exceptions, such as an exception for <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a> products, Trump promised higher rates, broader impacts, and few exceptions in his second term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sherman-2025a_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman-2025a-372"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Tax_Foundation" title="Tax Foundation">Tax Foundation</a>, the first Trump administration imposed new tariffs on approximately $380 billion worth of imports. Comparatively, the second Trump administration was expected to impact more than $1.4 trillion of imports by April 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-York-2025_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-York-2025-374"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>At the start of his second term, confusion over rapidly fluctuating tariff levels and other economic policies created significant uncertainty for businesses and economists,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> creating a chaotic environment for investment, business planning, and pricing, and posing serious concerns for consumers as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> US GDP grew by 2.8% in 2024, the year before Trump's inauguration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cohen-2025_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cohen-2025-378"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In March 2025, the Federal Reserve lowered its 2025 growth forecast from 2.1% to 1.7%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harring-2025_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harring-2025-379"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while the OECD projected a decline to 2.2% in 2025 and 1.6% in 2026.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cohen-2025_378-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cohen-2025-378"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Federal Reserve also increased average inflation expectations from 2.5% to 2.7%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harring-2025_379-1"><a href="#cite_note-Harring-2025-379"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The US dollar value also decreased massively following the announcement compared to other currencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a> estimated that tariffs imposed by Trump would remove up to 500,000 jobs in the US; thousands of layoffs had already taken place as of April 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By April 4, <a href="/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase" title="JPMorgan Chase">JPMorgan Chase</a> forecasted a recession within the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As noted in April 2025 by the editor of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i>, Trump’s imposition of sudden and extreme tariffs fails to account for the fact that US-produced goods “[have] long supply chains, where companies get supplies from many different countries, and where the US has specialized in services and higher <a href="/wiki/Value_added" title="Value added">value-add</a> manufacturers.”<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Furthermore, if the end goal is to rebuild domestic manufacturing by implementing permanently high tariffs, not only would parts and materials likely become difficult or impossible to acquire, but, seeing as the United States only accounts for 15% of global trade, the international system is capable of carrying on with a reduced US role—a scenario which may well prove detrimental to the U.S. economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The expected impact of the threatened 25% tariffs on Mexican and Canadian goods is high. Grocery prices were expected to rise as two-thirds of US vegetable imports came from Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sherman-2025a_372-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman-2025a-372"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Peterson_Institute_for_International_Economics" title="Peterson Institute for International Economics">Peterson Institute for International Economics</a> estimated that such a tariff retained through 2029 would reduce the gross domestic product of the United States by <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$200</span> billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StevisGridneff_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-StevisGridneff-388"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to the Budget Lab at <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale University</a>, American households would lose approximately <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$1,200</span> in purchasing power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Early April 2025 saw a 64% drop in ocean container bookings from China to the US, a collapse of trade with the potential to cause retail shortages within a month or two.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Supply chain problems also loom for medicines such as the blood thinner <a href="/wiki/Heparin" title="Heparin">heparin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Medical device makers have also raised alarm over potential disruptions to their integrated global supply chains. Surgical tools, MRIs, ventilators, pumps and other equipment are likely to rise in price.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>392<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following Trump’s global tariff announcements and worldwide trade war on April 3,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cohen_432025_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cohen_432025-393"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>393<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the Yale Budget Lab calculated the average effective US tariff to be 22%, up from 11% before the announcement and at the highest level since 1909.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rappeport_432025_59-2"><a href="#cite_note-Rappeport_432025-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Inflation Insights stated the weighted average tariff rate was set to rise to around 25% to 30%, up from 2% in the prior year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cato_Institute" title="Cato Institute">Cato Institute</a> and other economists stated that the tariffs would "approach levels not seen since the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Smoot-Hawley_Tariff_Act" title="Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act">Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act</a> of 1930",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rappeport_422025_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rappeport_422025-396"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> put at roughly 20% and lasted until the <a href="/wiki/General_Agreement_on_Tariffs_and_Trade" title="General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade">General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade</a> in 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After adjusting for inflation, the tariffs amounted to the largest tax hike in U.S. history and triple the tax increase to fight World War II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Economist <a href="/wiki/Michael_Hudson_(economist)" title="Michael Hudson (economist)">Michael Hudson</a> has argued that the tariffs have the <a href="/wiki/Deglobalization#Risks_of_deglobalization" title="Deglobalization">potential to disrupt</a> the global economy by disrupting the <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_payments" title="Balance of payments">balance of payments</a> between the United States and its foreign debtors. By reducing the export trade between the United States and countries targeted by the tariffs and raising the cost of dollar-denominated goods, the US makes it more difficult for those countries to pay their dollar debts. Hudson believes this could cause a debt crisis, and compares it to the historical examples of the <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_debt_crisis" title="Latin American debt crisis">Latin American debt crisis</a> and the inter-allied repayment of loans during the <a href="/wiki/World_war" title="World war">World Wars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Political_and_legal_challenges">Political and legal challenges</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=56" title="Edit section: Political and legal challenges"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Senators <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Grassley" title="Chuck Grassley">Chuck Grassley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maria_Cantwell" title="Maria Cantwell">Maria Cantwell</a> introduced the bipartisan <a href="/wiki/Trade_Review_Act" title="Trade Review Act">Trade Review Act of 2025</a>, proposing amendments to the law aimed at <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a> and closing legal loopholes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>400<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, the law has not yet reached a consensus. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senate_Majority_Leader" title="Senate Majority Leader">Senate Majority Leader</a> <a href="/wiki/John_Thune" title="John Thune">John Thune</a> referred dismissively, "I don't think that has a future."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Senator <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Warren" title="Elizabeth Warren">Elizabeth Warren</a>, calling it "a moment of truth for Republicans" to overturn the emergency declaration that President Trump used to justify tariffs impacting the families, businesses, and farmers they represent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>402<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A similar bill was introduced in the House of Representatives by Rep. <a href="/wiki/Don_Bacon" title="Don Bacon">Don Bacon</a>, who stated, "The Constitution clearly gives the authority for taxes and tariffs to Congress. Our Founders created checks and balances for a reason," urging Congress to reclaim its responsibility.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>403<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Lawmakers were also frustrated with how the world learned of Trump's decisions—through a social media platform operated by <a href="/wiki/Trump_Media_%26_Technology_Group" title="Trump Media &amp; Technology Group">Trump's company</a>, instead of through federal administration officials.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Democratic Senator <a href="/wiki/Adam_Schiff" title="Adam Schiff">Adam Schiff</a> called on Congress to investigate whether Trump had engaged in suspicious <a href="/wiki/Insider_trading" title="Insider trading">insider trading</a> or <a href="/wiki/Market_manipulation" title="Market manipulation">market manipulation</a> when he abruptly announced and paused the tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SW_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-SW-166"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The media described the US economy, the government's handling of the jobs and retirement savings of millions of Americans, and the US's standing in global security, as having encountered an unprecedented crisis of trust because of the Trump administration's unrestrained behavior.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>406<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Companies, business groups, trade associations, lawyers at home and abroad, and foreign governments filed formal complaints challenging the legality of the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a> tariff measures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>408<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>409<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>411<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 16, 2025, <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a> Governor <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Newsom" title="Gavin Newsom">Gavin Newsom</a> sued Trump over tariffs in an aggressive move to end the president’s stranglehold on global commerce.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>412<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>413<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arizona" title="Arizona">Arizona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colorado" title="Colorado">Colorado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Delaware" title="Delaware">Delaware</a>, <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minnesota" title="Minnesota">Minnesota</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nevada" title="Nevada">Nevada</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">New Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">New York</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oregon" title="Oregon">Oregon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vermont" title="Vermont">Vermont</a> also sued Trump Administration over tariffs on April 23.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>414<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 14, 2025, a <a href="/wiki/Public_interest" title="Public interest">public interest</a> law firm, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Liberty_Justice_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Liberty Justice Center (page does not exist)">Liberty Justice Center</a>, filed suit against the Trump administration over Executive Order 14257 on behalf of a group of five small businesses in the case <i><a href="/wiki/V.O.S._Selections,_Inc._v._Trump" title="V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. Trump">V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. Trump</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>415<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The firm requested a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>416<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which was denied by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Court_of_International_Trade" title="United States Court of International Trade">United States Court of International Trade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>417<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Court set a briefing schedule and hearing to rule on plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction to enjoin the implementation of the Liberation Day tariffs. The government's response brief was filed on April 29 and the plaintiff's reply is due on May 6, 2025. The hearing is scheduled for May 13, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>418<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A closely related area of legal scrutiny arises from the broader constitutional and statutory questions surrounding the use of the <a href="/wiki/International_Emergency_Economic_Powers_Act" title="International Emergency Economic Powers Act">International Emergency Economic Powers Act</a> (IEEPA) as a basis for imposing tariffs. While the specific circumstances and plaintiffs differ across <i>Webber v. Trump</i>, <i>Princess Awesome &amp; Stonemaier Games v. Customs</i>, <i>Learning Resources v. Trump</i>, <i>Oregon v. Trump</i>, and <i>Emily Ley Paper Inc. v.
