Trump</i>, these cases collectively raise common concerns about the scope of presidential authority under IEEPA and its alignment with constitutional principles. Central to each case is the argument that the imposition of tariffs, in the absence of clear congressional authorization, may constitute an overextension of executive power into areas that are traditionally reserved for the legislative branch, particularly in the regulation of commerce and the imposition of tariffs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DS_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-DS-419"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>419<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TE_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-TE-420"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PC_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-PC-421"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>421<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A recurring issue in these challenges is the conflict between statutory interpretation and constitutional framework. Plaintiffs consistently argue that IEEPA was not intended to authorize broad-based trade measures without a defined national emergency and that its application in this context raises concerns regarding the separation of powers. Several complaints also invoke the nondelegation doctrine, asserting that the statute, as applied, grants the executive branch an excessively broad scope of discretion without adequate guiding principles. In addition to constitutional claims, the cases highlight the significant economic consequences for states, businesses, and individuals, emphasizing the potential for such executive actions to set a precedent for expansive policymaking beyond the original purpose of emergency economic legislation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DS_419-1"><a href="#cite_note-DS-419"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>419<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TE_420-1"><a href="#cite_note-TE-420"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PC_421-1"><a href="#cite_note-PC-421"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>421<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="China_2">China</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=57" title="Edit section: China"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Nomura_Holdings" title="Nomura Holdings">Nomura Holdings</a> estimated that eliminating the US <i>de minimis</i> exemption for Chinese goods "would slow Chinese export growth by 1.3 percentage points and GDP growth by 0.2 point".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hall-2025_88-2"><a href="#cite_note-Hall-2025-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> When the US Congress raised the <i>de minimis</i> limit from $200 to $800 in 2016, they sparked a surge in US imports of cheap Chinese goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hall-2025_88-3"><a href="#cite_note-Hall-2025-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A 2023 US <a href="/wiki/Select_or_special_committee_(United_States_Congress)" title="Select or special committee (United States Congress)">House Select Committee</a> report estimated that "nearly half" of all <i>de minimis</i> shipments originated from China. Chinese e-commerce companies <a href="/wiki/Temu" title="Temu">Temu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shein" title="Shein">Shein</a>, estimated to comprise more than 30% of daily <i>de minimis</i> exemptions to the US, onboarded more sellers with a physical presence in the US and expanded their distribution facilities beyond China, to mitigate the impact of losing the exemption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNBC-2025_90-1"><a href="#cite_note-CNBC-2025-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smith-2025_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-Smith-2025-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On February 7, 2025, Trump suspended closing the exemption for China until the Secretary of Commerce notified him that adequate systems to process and collect tariff revenue were in place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNBC-2025_90-2"><a href="#cite_note-CNBC-2025-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The exemption is expected to be closed again on May 3, 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>422<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Other_countries_2">Other countries</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=58" title="Edit section: Other countries"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ontario" title="Ontario">Ontario</a> Premier <a href="/wiki/Doug_Ford" title="Doug Ford">Doug Ford</a> stated that the tariffs would likely affect around half a million jobs in the province's automotive industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StevisGridneff_388-1"><a href="#cite_note-StevisGridneff-388"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Marcus Noland, Director of Studies at the Peterson Institute, believed the tariffs would lead to deindustrialization in Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StevisGridneff_388-2"><a href="#cite_note-StevisGridneff-388"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In Singapore, <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Singapore" title="Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore">Deputy Prime Minister</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Trade_and_Industry_(Singapore)" title="Ministry of Trade and Industry (Singapore)">Minister for Trade and Industry</a> <a href="/wiki/Gan_Kim_Yong" title="Gan Kim Yong">Gan Kim Yong</a>, along with Senior Minister <a href="/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong" title="Lee Hsien Loong">Lee Hsien Loong</a>, expressed concerns that the tariffs could affect economic growth and the cost of living. Gan stated in a press briefing that authorities were monitoring the situation and would implement measures if necessary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>424<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Analysts in Singapore noted that while the tariffs posed a risk of trade slowdown, they could also make Singapore a more attractive source of imports for American buyers seeking alternatives to higher-taxed suppliers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>425<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In response to Trump's vehicle tariffs, some automobile companies suspended exports to the U.S., including <a href="/wiki/Audi" title="Audi">Audi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaguar_Cars" title="Jaguar Cars">Jaguar</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Land_Rover" title="Land Rover">Land Rover</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>426<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On April 5, 2025, Japanese video game manufacturer <a href="/wiki/Nintendo" title="Nintendo">Nintendo</a> announced it would delay pre-orders for its upcoming <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_Switch_2" title="Nintendo Switch 2">Switch 2</a> console from their initial date of April 9 in the United States, citing economic uncertainty due to the tariffs. However, the console's planned U.S. release date of June 5 remained unchanged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>427<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>One of the worst affected countries is <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, the second largest textile exporter in the world, which holds roughly 8% of the US textile market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kaler_Kantho_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kaler_Kantho-428"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>428<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> described it as a "massive blow" for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Textile_industry_of_Bangladesh" title="Textile industry of Bangladesh">textile industry of Bangladesh</a>, which contributes 80% of the country's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kaler_Kantho_428-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kaler_Kantho-428"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>428<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/France24" title="France24">France24</a></i> reported that many US buyers started to halt orders in the country following imposition of reciprocal tariffs, saying that it was too costly for them to bear a 37% tariff.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>429<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2025, Trump said that the tariffs on Mexico are intended to reduce the U.S. trade deficit with Mexico and force the country to secure its border with the United States against <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration_into_the_United_States" title="Illegal immigration into the United States">illegal immigration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fentanyl" title="Fentanyl">fentanyl</a> smuggling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>430<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Opioid_epidemic_in_the_United_States" title="Opioid epidemic in the United States">opioid crisis in the United States</a> is largely fueled by drugs smuggled from Mexico; approximately 98% of fentanyl entering the U.S. comes from Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> During the first months of 2025, Mexico stepped up its fight against narcotraffic and immigration following Trump's statements on the subject. In particular, Mexico handed over 29 major cartel prisoners to US authorities in February 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>432<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Summary_table">Summary table</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=59" title="Edit section: Summary table"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>

<td>25% tariff on most Canadian goods
</td>

<td>Partially in effect
</td>
<td>Tariffs on USMCA-compliant goods are delayed indefinitely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CM_77-2"><a href="#cite_note-CM-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 38% of Canadian goods were compliant in 2024,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zahn-2025_192-2"><a href="#cite_note-Zahn-2025-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but Canada expected the "vast majority" of goods to be quickly made compliant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>437<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shalal-2025_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-Shalal-2025-438"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>10% tariff on Canadian oil and gas
</td>
<td>February 1, 2025
</td>
<td>March 4, 2025
</td>
<td>Delayed
</td>
<td>Delayed indefinitely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CM_77-3"><a href="#cite_note-CM-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shalal-2025_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-Shalal-2025-438"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>145% tariff on all Chinese goods
</td>
<td>February 1, 2025
</td>
<td>February 4, 2025; Increased March 4, 2025; Increased April 9
</td>
<td><b>In effect</b>
</td>
<td>Total tariff of 145% includes:
<ul><li>20% "fentanyl tariff" (10% on 2/4/25 + 10% on 3/4/25)</li>
<li>125% "reciprocal tariff" (34% initial tariff + 50% retaliation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>439<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> + 41% retaliation).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HA_160-1"><a href="#cite_note-HA-160"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Not applicable to <a class="mw-selflink-fragment" href="#Excluded_goods">§ Excluded goods</a>.</li></ul>
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCarthy-2025_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-McCarthy-2025-440"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>440<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Doherty_110-1"><a href="#cite_note-Doherty-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CT_436-2"><a href="#cite_note-CT-436"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>436<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>25% tariff on all Mexican goods
</td>
<td>February 1, 2025</td>
<td>March 4, 2025</td>
<td>Partially in effect</td>
<td>Tariffs on USMCA-compliant goods are delayed indefinitely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CM_77-4"><a href="#cite_note-CM-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 50% of Mexican goods were compliant in 2024, but Mexico planned to increase to 85–90%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Martinez-2025_193-1"><a href="#cite_note-Martinez-2025-193"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shalal-2025_438-2"><a href="#cite_note-Shalal-2025-438"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th colspan="6">Foreign retaliation
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>Country/Region
</th>
<th>Announced
</th>
<th>Effective
</th>
<th>Status
</th>
<th>Notes
</th>
<th>Ref
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>Canada
</td>
<td>February 1, 2025
</td>
<td>March 4, 2025
</td>
<td><b>In effect<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gillies-2025_195-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gillies-2025-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></b>
</td>
<td>25% on $20.8 bn (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$30 bn</span>) of US goods in effect. A planned expansion to an additional $86 bn (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$125 bn</span>) worth of US goods was suspended on March 6.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gillies-2025_195-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gillies-2025-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Murray-2025_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-Murray-2025-441"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>441<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StevisGridneff-2025_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-StevisGridneff-2025-442"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>442<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Canada
</td>
<td>March 12, 2025
</td>
<td>March 13, 2025
</td>
<td><b>In effect</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>443<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td>25% tariffs on $20.6 bn (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$29.8 bn</span>) of US goods: $8.7 bn (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$12.6 bn</span>) steel products, $2 bn (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$3 bn</span>) aluminum products, and $9.9 bn (<span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$14.2 bn</span>) misc. goods.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SR_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-SR-197"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Canada
</td>
<td>April 4, 2025
</td>
<td>April 9, 2025
</td>
<td><b>In effect</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>444<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td>25% tariff on non-USMCA compliant vehicles imported into Canada from the US. Auto parts will not be impacted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KI_198-1"><a href="#cite_note-KI-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>445<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KI_198-2"><a href="#cite_note-KI-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>China
</td>
<td>February 1, 2025
</td>
<td>February 4, 2025
</td>
<td><b>In effect</b>
</td>
<td>15% tariff on coals and <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas" title="Liquefied natural gas">liquefied natural gas</a>, 10% on oil and agricultural machines, and investigations on U.S. companies.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xiao-2025_206-2"><a href="#cite_note-Xiao-2025-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>China
</td>
<td>March 4, 2025
</td>
<td>March 10, 2025
</td>
<td><b>In effect</b>
</td>
<td>10–15% tariffs on U.S. meat and agricultural products, suspension of U.S. lumber imports, revocation of soybean import licenses for 3 U.S. firms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-210"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPR-2025_207-1"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-2025-207"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>China
</td>
<td>April 4, 2025
</td>
<td>April 10, 2025
</td>
<td><b>In effect</b>
</td>
<td>Originally 34% on all US goods effective April 10, China raised the baseline to 84% on April 9 and 125% on April 12.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>446<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>447<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>China
</td>
<td>April 11, 2025
</td>
<td>April 11, 2025
</td>
<td><b>In effect</b>
</td>
<td>China suspends exports of a range of minerals and magnets critical to auto, defense, aerospace, and semiconductor industries; the Chinese government plans to introduce a new regulatory system to prevent access to American companies.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WI_217-2"><a href="#cite_note-WI-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>European Union
</td>
<td>March 12, 2025
</td>
<td>April 15, 2025
</td>
<td>Delayed for 90 days
</td>
<td>25% tariffs on $23.8 bn (€21 bn) of US goods, targeting farm produce and $13.5 bn products from Republican states (reduced from an initial threat of €26bn to begin April 1).
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RT_311-2"><a href="#cite_note-RT-311"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th colspan="6">Proposed US tariffs
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>25% on countries importing Venezuelan oil
</td>
<td>March 24, 2025
</td>
<td>April 2, 2025
</td>
<td>Announced
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State" title="United States Secretary of State">Secretary of State</a> may impose a 25% tariff on goods from any country that imports Venezuelan oil, directly or indirectly, after April 2, 2025. In 2024, China imported 68% of Venezuelan oil.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boak-2025b_99-1"><a href="#cite_note-Boak-2025b-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Digital Service Taxes (DSTs)
</td>
<td>February 21, 2025
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>Trump directed USTR to initiate a Section 301 investigation into DSTs, particularly against France, Austria, Italy, Spain, Turkey, and the UK
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen-2025_95-4"><a href="#cite_note-Allen-2025-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Copper
</td>
<td>February 25, 2025
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>Trump directed the Commerce Secretary to initiate a Section 232 investigation into copper imports.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Timber and lumber
</td>
<td>March 1, 2025
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>Trump directed the Commerce Secretary to initiate a Section 232 investigation into timber and lumber imports.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Swanson-2025_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-Swanson-2025-449"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>449<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Pharmaceuticals
</td>
<td>April 1, 2025
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>Trump directed the Commerce Secretary to initiate a Section 232 investigation into “pharmaceuticals and pharmaceutical ingredients, including finished drug products”.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DP_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-DP-450"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>450<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Semiconductors
</td>
<td>April 1, 2025
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>Trump directed the Commerce Secretary to initiate a Section 232 investigation into “imports of semiconductors and semiconductor manufacturing equipment”.
</td>
<td><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DP_450-1"><a href="#cite_note-DP-450"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>450<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Processed critical minerals and derivative products
</td>
<td>April 22, 2025
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>Trump directed the Commerce Secretary to initiate a Section 232 investigation into "imports of processed critical minerals, as well as their derivative products".
</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Trucks and truck parts
</td>
<td>April 22, 2025
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>Trump directed the Commerce Secretary to initiate a Section 232 investigation into "imports of medium-duty trucks, heavy-duty, trucks, and medium- and heavy-duty truck parts, and their derivative products".
</td>
<td>
</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="References">References</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration&amp;action=edit&amp;section=62" title="Edit section: References"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239543626">.mw-parser-output .reflist{margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}@media screen{.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%}}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist">

<li id="cite_note-irishtimes/picture-reciprocal-tariffs-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-irishtimes/picture-reciprocal-tariffs_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-irishtimes/picture-reciprocal-tariffs_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

</li>
<li id="cite_note-MJ-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-MJ_14-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-MJ_14-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFNeiman2025">Neiman, Brent (April 7, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/07/opinion/trump-tariff-math-formula.html" rel="nofollow">"Why Trump's Tariff Math Is a Joke"</a>. Opinion. <i>The New York Times</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331" rel="nofollow">0362-4331</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Multiple sources:
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2021/02/10/new-data-show-the-failures-of-donald-trumps-china-trade-strategy" rel="nofollow">"New data show the failures of Donald Trump's China trade strategy"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i>. February 10, 2021.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=New+data+show+the+failures+of+Donald+Trump%27s+China+trade+strategy&amp;rft.date=2021-02-10&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fgraphic-detail%2F2021%2F02%2F10%2Fnew-data-show-the-failures-of-donald-trumps-china-trade-strategy&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-11/how-china-won-trump-s-good-and-easy-to-win-trade-war" rel="nofollow">"How China Won Trump's Trade War and Got Americans to Foot the Bill"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_News" title="Bloomberg News">Bloomberg L.P.</a> January 11, 2021.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=How+China+Won+Trump%27s+Trade+War+and+Got+Americans+to+Foot+the+Bill&amp;rft.date=2021-01-11&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fnews%2Farticles%2F2021-01-11%2Fhow-china-won-trump-s-good-and-easy-to-win-trade-war&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFPicciotto2024">Picciotto, Rebecca (October 23, 2024). <a class="external text" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2024/10/23/nobel-prize-winning-economists-donald-trump-agenda-endorse-harris.html" rel="nofollow">"<span class="cs1-kern-left"></span>'Higher prices, larger deficits': 23 Nobel Prize-winning economists slam Trump agenda, endorse Harris"</a>. <li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFLooneyPatel2025">Looney, Adam; Patel, Elena (January 15, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.brookings.edu/articles/why-does-the-executive-branch-have-so-much-power-over-tariffs/" rel="nofollow">"Why does the executive branch have so much power over tariffs?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Brookings_Institution" title="Brookings Institution">Brookings Institution</a></i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Brookings+Institution&amp;rft.atitle=Why+does+the+executive+branch+have+so+much+power+over+tariffs%3F&amp;rft.date=2025-01-15&amp;rft.aulast=Looney&amp;rft.aufirst=Adam&amp;rft.au=Patel%2C+Elena&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.brookings.edu%2Farticles%2Fwhy-does-the-executive-branch-have-so-much-power-over-tariffs%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Christopher-T-Zirpoli-2025-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Christopher-T-Zirpoli-2025_53-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Christopher-T-Zirpoli-2025_53-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation report cs1" id="CITEREFChristopher_T._Zirpoli2025">Christopher T. Congressional Research Service. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/R/R48435" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on March 1, 2025<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFSpangler2025">Spangler, Todd (March 27, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.freep.com/story/news/politics/2025/03/27/trump-auto-tariffs-section-232-national-security-explained/82688081007/" rel="nofollow">"Trump bases auto tariffs on national security. </li>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-98">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFKutz2025">Kutz, Anna (March 25, 2025). <a class="external text" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20250327192617/https://thehill.com/homenews/5211102-what-are-secondary-tariffs-trump-says-theyll-soon-hit-venezuela/" rel="nofollow">"What are 'secondary tariffs'? </li>
<li id="cite_note-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-113">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFHarithasMengBrownMouradian2025">Harithas, Barath; Meng, Kyle; Brown, Evan; Mouradian, Catharine (April 3, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.csis.org/analysis/liberation-day-tariffs-explained" rel="nofollow">"Liberation Day Tariffs Explained"</a>. <i>Center for Strategic and International Studies</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">April 7,</span> 2025</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Center+for+Strategic+and+International+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Liberation+Day+Tariffs+Explained&amp;rft.date=2025-04-03&amp;rft.aulast=Harithas&amp;rft.aufirst=Barath&amp;rft.au=Meng%2C+Kyle&amp;rft.au=Brown%2C+Evan&amp;rft.au=Mouradian%2C+Catharine&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.csis.org%2Fanalysis%2Fliberation-day-tariffs-explained&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-NYTcalc-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NYTcalc_127-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFRommSwansonGamio2025">Romm, Tony; Swanson, Ana; Gamio, Lazaro (April 3, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/02/business/economy/trump-tariff-rates-calculation.html" rel="nofollow">"How Are Trump's Tariff Rates Calculated?"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331" rel="nofollow">0362-4331</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-143">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFDorn">Dorn, Sara. <a class="external text" href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/saradorn/2025/04/18/trump-approval-rating-tracker-majority-disapprove-of-trump--and-powell-in-latest-poll/" rel="nofollow">"Trump Approval Rating Tracker: Majority Disapprove Of Trump— And Powell—In Latest Poll"</a>. <i>Forbes</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-174"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-174">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFPhillips2024">Phillips, Tom (November 28, 2024). <a class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2024/nov/28/sheinbaum-trump-mexico-tariffs" rel="nofollow">"Sheinbaum responds to Trump's tariff threats against Mexico"</a>. <i>The Guardian</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-189"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-189">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFPutzierLahart2025">Putzier, Konrad; Lahart, Justin (March 3, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20250304055239/https://www.wsj.com/economy/trade/trump-tariffs-usher-in-new-era-of-protectionism-a50a90f1" rel="nofollow">"Trump Tariffs Usher in New Era of Protectionism"</a>. <i>The Wall Street Journal</i>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://www.wsj.com/economy/trade/trump-tariffs-usher-in-new-era-of-protectionism-a50a90f1" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on March 4, 2025<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-203">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFBown2022">Bown, Chad P. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">April 27,</span> 2025</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.piie.com&amp;rft.atitle=China+bought+none+of+the+extra+%24200+billion+of+US+exports+in+Trump%27s+trade+deal+%7C+PIIE&amp;rft.date=2022-02-08&amp;rft.aulast=Bown&amp;rft.aufirst=Chad+P.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.piie.com%2Fblogs%2Frealtime-economics%2F2022%2Fchina-bought-none-extra-200-billion-us-exports-trumps-trade-deal&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-reuters2025china-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-reuters2025china_213-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.reuters.com/world/china-japan-south-korea-will-jointly-respond-us-tariffs-chinese-state-media-says-2025-03-31/" rel="nofollow">"China, Japan, South Korea will jointly respond to US tariffs, Chinese state media says"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">Reuters</a></i>. Beijing. April 1, 2025. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20250331222358/https://www.reuters.com/world/china-japan-south-korea-will-jointly-respond-us-tariffs-chinese-state-media-says-2025-03-31/" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on March 31, 2025<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">April 1,</span> 2025</span>. <q>Japan and South Korea are seeking to import semiconductor raw materials from China, and China is also interested in purchasing chip products from Japan and South Korea, the account, Yuyuan Tantian, said in a post on Weibo.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Reuters&amp;rft.atitle=China%2C+Japan%2C+South+Korea+will+jointly+respond+to+US+tariffs%2C+Chinese+state+media+says&amp;rft.date=2025-04-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.reuters.com%2Fworld%2Fchina-japan-south-korea-will-jointly-respond-us-tariffs-chinese-state-media-says-2025-03-31%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-216"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-216">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFHarwellZakrzewskiHaxAllison2025">Harwell, Drew; Zakrzewski, Cat; Hax, Carolyn; Allison, Natalie; Stein, Jeff; Birnbaum, Michael; Rampell, Catherine; Singletary, Michelle; Lynch, David J. <li id="cite_note-WI-217"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WI_217-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WI_217-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WI_217-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFBradsher2025">Bradsher, Keith (April 13, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/13/business/china-rare-earths-exports.html" rel="nofollow">"China Halts Critical Exports as Trade War Intensifies"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331" rel="nofollow">0362-4331</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">April 14,</span> 2025</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=China+Halts+Critical+Exports+as+Trade+War+Intensifies&amp;rft.date=2025-04-13&amp;rft.issn=0362-4331&amp;rft.aulast=Bradsher&amp;rft.aufirst=Keith&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2025%2F04%2F13%2Fbusiness%2Fchina-rare-earths-exports.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></span>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-VE-262"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-VE_262-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-VE_262-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMinh2025">Minh, Ethan (March 17, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://sourcevietnam.com/blog/how-trump-tariffs-impact-vietnamese-exports" rel="nofollow">"How Trump 2.0 Tariffs May Impact Vietnamese Exports"</a>. <i>SourceVietNam</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-277"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-277">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFVenley2025">Venley, Nanji Nandang (April 3, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.icirnigeria.org/trump-imposes-14-tariff-on-nigerian-exports-to-us/?utm_source=chatgpt.com" rel="nofollow">"Trump imposes 14% tariff on Nigerian exports to US"</a>. <i>The ICIR- Latest News, Politics, Governance, Elections, Investigation, Factcheck, Covid-19</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-309"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-309">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFReid2025">Reid, Jenni (April 10, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2025/04/10/european-union-to-put-countermeasures-to-us-tariffs-on-hold-for-90-days.html" rel="nofollow">"European Union to put countermeasures to U.S. tariffs on hold for 90 days"</a>. <i>CNBC</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-343"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-343">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFTABUREGUCI2025">TABUREGUCI, DIONISIA (February 21, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.fijitimes.com.fj/economy-strong-tariff-war-no-impact/?" rel="nofollow">"Economy strong, tariff war no impact"</a>. <i>The Fiji Times</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-373"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-373">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFSwanson2025">Swanson, Ana (March 10, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/10/business/economy/trump-tariffs-exceptions.html" rel="nofollow">"Trump Has Said 'No Exceptions' to His Tariffs. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 19,</span> 2025</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Trump+Has+Said+%27No+Exceptions%27+to+His+Tariffs.+Will+That+Last%3F&amp;rft.date=2025-03-10&amp;rft.issn=0362-4331&amp;rft.aulast=Swanson&amp;rft.aufirst=Ana&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2025%2F03%2F10%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Ftrump-tariffs-exceptions.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></span>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-StevisGridneff-388"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-StevisGridneff_388-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-StevisGridneff_388-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-StevisGridneff_388-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFStevis-GridneffSwansonRomero2025">Stevis-Gridneff, Matina; Swanson, Ana; Romero, Simon (January 21, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/21/world/canada/trumps-tariffs-us-canada-mexico.html" rel="nofollow">"How Could Trump's Tariffs Affect the U.S., Canada and Mexico?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20250201081128/https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/21/world/canada/trumps-tariffs-us-canada-mexico.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on February 1, 2025<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-397"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-397">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFDouglasFairless2025">Douglas, Jason; Fairless, Tom (March 24, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.wsj.com/economy/trade/trade-war-explodes-across-world-at-pace-not-seen-in-decades-0b6d6513?mod=hp_lead_pos7" rel="nofollow">"Trade War Explodes Across World at Pace Not Seen in Decades"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-403"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-403">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.aol.com/u-rep-don-bacon-proposes-000017944.html" rel="nofollow">"U.S. Rep. </li>
<li id="cite_note-DS-419"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-DS_419-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-DS_419-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMangan2025">Mangan, Dan (April 23, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2025/04/23/states-sue-trump-in-bid-to-block-new-tariffs.html" rel="nofollow">"Dozen states sue Trump in bid to block new tariffs"</a>. <i>CNBC</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-u470-434"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-u470_434-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/02/18/2025-02832/adjusting-imports-of-aluminum-into-the-united-states" rel="nofollow">"Adjusting Imports of Aluminum Into the United States"</a>. <i>Federal Register</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 12,</span> 2025</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Trump+Trade+Dispute+With+Canada+Escalates+Over+Lumber&amp;rft.date=2025-03-01&amp;rft.aulast=Swanson&amp;rft.aufirst=Ana&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2025%2F03%2F01%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Ftrump-trade-canada-lumber.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-DP-450"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-DP_450-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-DP_450-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFMullerDlouhy2025">Muller, Madison; Dlouhy, Jennifer A (April 14, 2025). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20250414213749/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-04-14/trump-moves-to-put-tariffs-on-chips-drugs-in-motion" rel="nofollow">"Trump Initiates Chips and Drug Probes, Ahead of More Tariffs"</a>. Bloomberg L.P. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-04-14/trump-moves-to-put-tariffs-on-chips-drugs-in-motion" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on April 14, 2025<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">April 14,</span> 2025</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Trump+Initiates+Chips+and+Drug+Probes%2C+Ahead+of+More+Tariffs&amp;rft.date=2025-04-14&amp;rft.aulast=Muller&amp;rft.aufirst=Madison&amp;rft.au=Dlouhy%2C+Jennifer+A&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fnews%2Farticles%2F2025-04-14%2Ftrump-moves-to-put-tariffs-on-chips-drugs-in-motion&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATariffs+in+the+second+Trump+administration"></span></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li><a href="/wiki/Tax_Reform_Act_of_1986" title="Tax Reform Act of 1986">1986</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Code_of_1986" title="Internal Revenue Code of 1986">1986 Code</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Omnibus_Budget_Reconciliation_Act_of_1987" title="Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987">1987</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Technical_and_Miscellaneous_Revenue_Act_of_1988" title="Technical and Miscellaneous Revenue Act of 1988">1988</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Omnibus_Budget_Reconciliation_Act_of_1990" title="Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990">1990</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Omnibus_Budget_Reconciliation_Act_of_1993" title="Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993">1993</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Taxpayer_Bill_of_Rights_2" title="Taxpayer Bill of Rights 2">1996</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Taxpayer_Relief_Act_of_1997" title="Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997">1997</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Service_Restructuring_and_Reform_Act_of_1998" title="Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998">1998</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Economic_Growth_and_Tax_Relief_Reconciliation_Act_of_2001" title="Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001">2001 (EGTRRA)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Job_Creation_and_Worker_Assistance_Act_of_2002" title="Job Creation and Worker Assistance Act of 2002">2002</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jobs_and_Growth_Tax_Relief_Reconciliation_Act_of_2003" title="Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003">2003</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/American_Jobs_Creation_Act_of_2004" title="American Jobs Creation Act of 2004">2004</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tax_Increase_Prevention_and_Reconciliation_Act_of_2005" title="Tax Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act of 2005">2005</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pension_Protection_Act_of_2006" title="Pension Protection Act of 2006">2006</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tax_Relief_and_Health_Care_Act_of_2006" title="Tax Relief and Health Care Act of 2006">2006</a></li>
<li><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tax_Increase_Prevention_Act_of_2007&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tax Increase Prevention Act of 2007 (page does not exist)">2007</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mortgage_Forgiveness_Debt_Relief_Act_of_2007" title="Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007">2007 (Mortgage)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Economic_Stimulus_Act_of_2008" title="Economic Stimulus Act of 2008">2008</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Public_Law_110-343" title="Public Law 110-343">Crisis</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009" title="American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009">2009</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act" title="Affordable Care Act">2010 (ACA)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Small_Business_Jobs_Act_of_2010" title="Small Business Jobs Act of 2010">2010 (PL 111–240)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tax_Relief,_Unemployment_Insurance_Reauthorization,_and_Job_Creation_Act_of_2010" title="Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010">2010 (PL 111-312)</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temporary_Payroll_Tax_Cut_Continuation_Act_of_2011" title="Temporary Payroll Tax Cut Continuation Act of 2011">2011</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/American_Taxpayer_Relief_Act_of_2012" title="American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012">2012 (ATRA)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Middle_Class_Tax_Relief_and_Job_Creation_Act_of_2012" title="Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012">2012</a></li>
<li><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tax_Increase_Prevention_Act_of_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tax Increase Prevention Act of 2014 (page does not exist)">2014</a></li>
<li><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bipartisan_Budget_Act_of_2015&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015 (page does not exist)">2015 (BBA)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Consolidated_Appropriations_Act,_2016" title="Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016">2016</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tax_Cuts_and_Jobs_Act_of_2017" title="Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017">2017 (TCJA)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bipartisan_Budget_Act_of_2018" title="Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018">2018 (BBA)</a></li>
<li><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Fourth_Continuing_Appropriations_for_Fiscal_Year_2018,_Federal_Register_Printing_Savings,_Healthy_Kids,_Health-Related_Taxes,_and_Budgetary_Effects&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Fourth Continuing Appropriations for Fiscal Year 2018, Federal Register Printing Savings, Healthy Kids, Health-Related Taxes, and Budgetary Effects (page does not exist)">2018 (Appropriations)</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SECURE_Act_of_2019" title="SECURE Act of 2019">2019 (SECURE)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Families_First_Coronavirus_Response_Act" title="Families First Coronavirus Response Act">2020 (Families First)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/CARES_Act" title="CARES Act">2020 (CARES)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Consolidated_Appropriations_Act,_2021" title="Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021">2020 (Appropriations)</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_M._(Mac)_Thornberry_National_Defense_Authorization_Act_for_Fiscal_Year_2021" title="William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021">2021 (Defense Authorization)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/American_Rescue_Plan_Act_of_2021" title="American Rescue Plan Act of 2021">2021 (American Rescue Plan)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Infrastructure_Investment_and_Jobs_Act" title="Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act">2021 (Infrastructure, PL 117–58)</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tariffs_in_United_States_history" title="Tariffs in United States history">Tariffs</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Tariff_of_1789" title="Tariff of 1789">1789: Hamilton I</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Tariff_of_1824" title="Tariff of 1824">1824: Sectional</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tariff_of_Abominations" title="Tariff of Abominations">1828: "Abominations"</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tariff_of_1832" title="Tariff of 1832">1832</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tariff_of_1833" title="Tariff of 1833">1833: Compromise</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tariff_of_1842" title="Tariff of 1842">1842: Black</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Walker_tariff" title="Walker tariff">1846: Walker</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tariff_of_1857" title="Tariff of 1857">1857</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Morrill_Tariff" title="Morrill Tariff">1861: Morrill</a></li>
<li>1872</li>
<li>1875</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tariff_of_1883" title="Tariff of 1883">1883: Mongrel</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/McKinley_Tariff" title="McKinley Tariff">1890: McKinley</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Wilson%E2%80%93Gorman_Tariff_Act" title="Wilson–Gorman Tariff Act">1894: Wilson–Gorman</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dingley_Act" title="Dingley Act">1897: Dingley</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Payne%E2%80%93Aldrich_Tariff_Act" title="Payne–Aldrich Tariff Act">1909: Payne–Aldrich</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Revenue_Act_of_1913" title="Revenue Act of 1913">1913: Underwood</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Emergency_Tariff_of_1921" title="Emergency Tariff of 1921">1921: Emergency</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fordney%E2%80%93McCumber_Tariff" title="Fordney–McCumber Tariff">1922: Fordney–McCumber</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Smoot%E2%80%93Hawley_Tariff_Act" title="Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act">1930: Smoot–Hawley</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Reciprocal_Tariff_Act" title="Reciprocal Tariff Act">1934: Reciprocal</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/General_Agreement_on_Tariffs_and_Trade" title="General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade">1948: GATT</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Trade_Expansion_Act" title="Trade Expansion Act">1962</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Trade_Act_of_1974" title="Trade Act of 1974">1974/75</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Trade_Agreements_Act_of_1979" title="Trade Agreements Act of 1979">1979</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Trade_and_Tariff_Act_of_1984" title="Trade and Tariff Act of 1984">1984</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Omnibus_Trade_and_Competitiveness_Act" title="Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act">1988</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement">1988: Canada FT</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">1993: NAFTA</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">1994: WTO</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tariffs_in_the_first_Trump_administration" title="Tariffs in the first Trump administration">2018/2019: Trump</a></li>

<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"Article","name":"Tariffs in the second Trump administration","url":"https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration","sameAs":"http:\/\/www.wikidata.org\/entity\/Q132099340","mainEntity":"http:\/\/www.wikidata.org\/entity\/Q132099340","author":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Contributors to Wikimedia projects"},"publisher":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Wikimedia Foundation, Inc.","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/www.wikimedia.org\/static\/images\/wmf-hor-googpub.png"}},"datePublished":"2024-11-26T01:01:58Z","dateModified":"2025-05-04T18:06:51Z","image":"https:\/\/upload.wikimedia.org\/wikipedia\/commons\/a\/a1\/Trump_showing_a_chart_with_reciprocal_tariffs_%28cropped%29.jpg","headline":"tariffs imposed by Donald Trump in his second term as president of the United States"}</script>
